div.p: The ocean covers nearly two-thirds of the surface on the Earth, and there has been great interest in developing underwater wireless sensor networks (UWSNs) to help us explore the ocean realm. A great deal of efforts have been devoted to it, and significant progress has been made since the beginning of 2000s. However, most of the networks are isolatedly developed currently, inherently hardware-based and application-oriented with inflexible closed-form architectures, which are difficult to reconfigure, reprogram and evolve. They also lack the capability in sharing resources, and are far from service-oriented networks. These limitations impair their capacity for wide range of applications. To further propel the development of UWSNs, next-generation UWSNs have been proposed recently, which are robust, flexible, adaptive, programmable, support resourcesharing feature and are easy to manage and evolve. Moreover, a number of novel software-defined techniques and paradigms, such as software-defined radio (SDR), cognitive acoustic radio (CAR), network function virtualization (NFV), software-defined networking (SDN), Internet of underwater things (IoUTs) and sensor-cloud, have been emerging. These software-defined technologies have the capability of softwarizing network resources, and then redefining them to satisfy diverse application requirements, improve resource utilization efficiency and simplify network management. Consequently, these evolving technologies are envisioned as critical building blocks and major driving forces, which will transform conventional UWSNs towards softwarebased, programmable, user-customizable and service-oriented next-generation UWSNs. In this paper, we provide a comprehensive review of existing works on implementing these techniques, and also present discussions for future research. We hope to inspire more active research on these areas and take a step further towards realizing next-generation UWSNs.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: Underwater wireless sensor networks (UWSNs) have been drawing attention of the research community since 2000, and significant advancements have been made in underwater modems, communication and network protocols [1]- [5]. However, the technologies have not been mature enough to be utilized broadly and meet diverse requirements of different applications. This is partly because of the constrained nature of resources, as well as inherent complexity of underwater communication channels. Consequently, extensive efforts have been devoted to tackle the problems of underwater communication systems by designing energy-efficient underwater sensor nodes (e.g., underwater acoustic modem) and communication system algorithms (e.g., MAC, network and application layers).

However, currently, most of the UWSNs are inherently hardware-based with inflexible, closed and rigid architectures, which are hard to reconfigure, reprogram and evolve [5]. Moreover, most of them are application-oriented and isolatedly developed, and so these networks lack the capability in sharing resources, supporting multi-application and are far from service-oriented networks [6]. Furthermore, new challenges are emerging which need to be tackled along with the development of UWSNs. For example, as UWSNs become larger, more heterogeneous underwater devices from different vendors are integrated into a single network, which require to improve interoperability feature of those assets to communicate with each other in a cooperative and seamless manner.

To further propel the development of UWSNs, nextgeneration UWSNs have been proposed recently, which are robust, flexible, adaptive with the ability to utilize energy and resources efficiently, and are easy to manage and evolve [5], [7], [8]. To make such networks a reality, new fundamental insights and bold visions should be developed as well as novel paradigms and techniques should be applied to them. Recently, some software-defined techniques, such as softwaredefined radio (SDR), cognitive acoustic radio (CAR), network virtualization, software-defined networks, sensor-cloud have been emerging [5], [9]- [12]. These evolving technologies are envisioned as critical building blocks and major driving forces that lead to the transformation of traditional UWSNs towards software-based, programmable, user-customizable and serviceoriented UWSNs.

One core principle behind those software-defined technolo- gies is the capability to softwarize network resources and then redefine those resources according to the requirements of different applications, which essentially enhances the utilization of resources and improves the efficiency of network management. The softwarization process is realized by flexible and programmable UWSNs. Generally, the ongoing research in this context focuses on three different levels, which are node level, network level and application level. From the aspects of programmability, those techniques have different priorities and advantages that target on different protocol layers.

A sample underwater software-defined architecture is illustrated in Fig. 1. In this architecture, SDR is integrated to software-defined underwater acoustic modem to enhance reconfigurability feature of both physical and MAC layers. On the other hand, cognitive radio (CR) is primarily used in order to exploit and utilize the dynamic characteristics of underwater spectrum. Software-defined networking (SDN) decouples the control logic of normal sensor nodes to the centralized controllers. Hence, higher layer functionalities are performed through well defined APIs to simplify network management [5]. NFV virtualizes network resources into softwarized entities to improve the resource sharing feature of sensor networks. Both Internet of Underwater Things (IoUTs) and cloud computing (sensor-cloud) can be regarded as application level technologies, which enable application-oriented sensor networks towards sensing-as-a-service networks [13], [14].

So far, significant effort has been made to improve programmability feature at the node level in order to handle complex underwater channels and design effective communication systems. Generally, other software-defined technologies are still in their infancy stages that require further development. However, we advocate that these emerging and novel software-defined technologies are powerful enough to transform conventional networks towards next-generation UWSNs. Additionally, although most of these technologies are developed isolatedly, some of them are complementary to each other. Therefore, those techniques could be combined and integrated together that create mutually strengthened force to tackle inherent problems of UWSNs and further propel their development.

In this paper, we present a comprehensive review on existing research of underwater software-defined architectures and technologies, and highlight their potential advantages on further extension in underwater domain. Several research directions are also discussed with the hope to identify unexplored areas for further research. Although there exist a number of surveys that focus on different aspects of UWSNs (e.g., channel characteristics, MAC, routing, topology control, localization, optical communication, testbeds, deployment and application scenarios) [1], [15]- [32], to the best of our knowledge, this paper is the first effort to provide a complete overview on software-defined technologies across multiple layers (e.g., physical, MAC, network and application layers). Moreover, it is also the first paper to discuss the issues related to SDR, CR, network function virtualization (NFV), SDN, IoUTs and cloud computing (e.g., sensor-cloud) concepts for the design of software-defined programmable architecture. The primary goal of this paper is to inspire more active research on software-defined UWSNs, and make a step further towards next-generation UWSNs.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. In Section II, we introduce the requirements of next-generation UWSNs, and then briefly describe the general characteristics of UWSNs, the design considerations of UWSNs as well as the related literature in this context. In Section III, we present a review on SDR enabling technologies, including software-defined acoustic modem and software-defined cognitive networks. In Section IV, the issues related to software-defined networking (SDN)enabled UWSNs are presented. The network virtualization concept in UWSNs is discussed in Section V. In Section VI, the potential of IoUTs and cloud computing technologies in this arena are presented. A brief summary of software-defined techniques and the future research directions are discussed in Section VII. Finally, the conclusions are drawn in Section VIII.

div.head: II. PRELIMINARIES AND BACKGROUND
div.p: In this section, we lay out related background information of UWSNs. More specifically, we discuss the requirements of next-generation UWSNs, then briefly describe the main characteristics of UWSNs, the design considerations of UWSNs, and finally report on the relevant literature. The terms related to this paper are listed in Table III.

div.head: A. Requirements of Next-Generation UWSNs
div.p: With the evolution of network technologies, a few papers discussed about next-generation UWSNs [5], [7]. We deem that next-generation UWSNs should be secure, reliable, efficient, robust, scalable, adaptable, evolvable and intelligent, a sample of which is shown in Fig. 2. Accordingly, to tackle inherent challenges of UWSNs and accelerate application development, the future UWSNs should have the following features.

-Flexibility and Adaptability: Traditional UWSNs are naturally hardware-based networks with rigid and inflexible architecture. However, to develop future service-oriented networks, these networks should provide reliable, user-customized and on-demand services to satisfy diverse and differentiated application requirements. Accordingly, in order to bring the network flexibility and adaptability features into reality, reprogrammable and reconfigurable architectures which are intelligent and agile enough to handle the dynamic and versatile communication environments, are required. Furthermore, the adaptable network should cope well with severely harsh communication environments as well as new requirements of applications in terms of differentiated QoS and security [5]. To design a robust, scalable and intelligent network, it also requires that the network is equipped with flexible and adaptive features. For example, an adaptive network should guarantee the scalability, i.e., a network still performs efficiently even when it scales up to a very large-scale one. Similarly, the network flexibility should prevent degradation of network performance while encountering network variation (e.g., node failure, change of topology and intermittent communication channel).

-Efficient Network Management: As UWSNs are generally resource constrained systems with limited computational capacity, memory, bandwidth and energy supply, managing such networks efficiently is a difficult task. In addition to that, both the inherent characteristics of the rigid hardwarebased ad-hoc sensor networks and the harsh ocean communication environments make the implementation of simplified network management even more challenging. Moreover, since the management of UWSNs covers several aspects of the sensor network (e.g., network configuration, topology control, QoS control, energy and power control, security, network maintenance, and mobility), to achieve optimized management efficiency is also a complicated and challenging task [33], [34].

-Interoperability: Along with the development of UWSNs, a large number of heterogeneous assets (e.g., various underwater modems, AUVs, USVs, ROVs, gliders, fixed or mobile buoys, vessels, subsea or surface sensor nodes) need to be integrated, and be interoperated with each other to perform specific tasks in a cooperative manner [35]. However, these heterogeneous devices and equipment are produced by different manufacturers based on inherent, inflexible and closed architectures, which are difficult to interoperate with each other while maintaining cooperation.

The standardization of protocol stack greatly facilitates the interoperability of these devices, which can be achievable in physical layer or network layer. However, standardizing heterogeneous devices among different manufactures is a slow and very difficult process as different vendors are concerned about product safety and have fear about the disclosure of commercial information. Consequently, it is difficult to reach a feasible consensus among them. An alternative option is to standardize the network layer via novel emerging softwaredefined technologies [5], [6]. For example, SDR can be integrated into the design of programmable underwater modems, in which the operational parameters, such as operating frequencies, modulation modes, can be reconfigured and reprogrammed at run-time to improve the interoperability of underwater devices.

-Multi-Modality: Conventional UWSNs mainly rely on lowdata-rate, long-range and high-delay acoustic links to transmit data and communicate with each other. With the advancement of emerging underwater communication technologies, such as optical and electromagnetic (EM), UWSNs have highdata-rate, short-distance and high-bandwidth complementary technologies to choose [25]. By jointly exploiting favorable features of multi-modal communications, the network performance can be greatly improved in terms of diverse data rate, communication range, delay, throughput, reliability as well as network coverage [5], [36].

Moreover, the available data rate and the maximum communication range are correlated with the operating frequencies of underwater acoustic modems. For example, at 24 kHz working frequency, the data transfer rate is about 4 kb/s for 2000 m communication range. Whereas, the data rate can reach up to 28 kb/s at 100 kHz working frequency, but the distance is decreased to about 100 m [37]. This characteristic could also be used for multi-modal communication by endowing a single modem to operate at multiple frequencies.

-Multi-Application: UWSNs are typically composed of expensive hardware components, and hence the deployment and maintenance costs of the network are high. However, conventional UWSNs are application-oriented, the protocols of which are heavily dependent on physical hardware components. Hence, a network which is designed for a specific application usually cannot be used for another application. Consequently, multiple UWSNs are required to be deployed in the same area for different applications, which lead to under-utilization of resources [5]. With the support of multiapplication design, a single well-designed network can support multiple applications by sharing the same physical infrastructure. For example, a deployed ocean monitoring network can also perform surveillance and tracking tasks in parallel (e.g., intrusion detection) in the same network.

-Sensing-as-a-Service: UWSNs are considered as the foundation of IoUTs, which aim to revolutionize the interaction among the submarine deployed smart devices and networks via the Internet [13], [14]. The development of emerging technologies recently (e.g., IoUTs, cloud computing and N-FV) makes sensing-as-a-service or infrastructure-as-a-service possible in underwater domain [5]. For example, IoUT aims to revolutionize interactions with submarine deployed smart devices and networks via the Internet [13], [14]. The paradigm of sensing-as-a-service enables UWSNs to provide on-demand services for user-defined requests from anyplace anytime by sharing underlying resources. The network hardware resources are virtualized and abstracted, and so sensing-as-a-service also revolutionizes the traditional application-specific sensor networks to service-oriented sensor networks. To realize the paradigm of sensing-as-a-service and IoUTs, underwater devices need to be IP-compatible, be accessed via gateways or interfaces and be smoothly connected with the cloud architecture [6], [12], [38].

-Security: Security is one critical foundation stone of a reliable UWSN. Usually, this type of networks are inherently vulnerable to a variety of malicious attacks [7], [39], [40]. As these networks are operated in harsh ocean environments, both the unreliable wireless communication channels and the mobility of the network as well as all insecure protocols leave rooms and expose the network for attacks. Moreover, when UWSNs are deployed for military surveillance applications (e.g., intrusion detection, target tracking), the nature of which are prone to bring severe security threats and attacks [41], [42].

Underwater malicious attacks aim at different layers (e.g., physical-, MAC-, network-and transport layer) in the form of jamming attack, wormhole attack, sinkhole attack or flooding attack [7]. These attacks either destroy sensor nodes or paralyze the entire network, which lead to degradation of network performance, disclosure of secret information or even network failure. Although security is a critical feature of UWSNs, it has not been paid enough attention. The architectural design of next-generation UWSNs should put more emphasis on network security, and leverage emerging software-defined technologies to create effective counteracting measures that improve network security.

-Network Evolvability: Evolvability is a critical feature for the adaptive evolution of networks. However, as most of the existing UWSNs have inflexible hardware-dependent architecture, they lack network evolvability for further innovation and improvement once these networks have been deployed. Therefore, when new technologies as well as new network control and management solutions appear, it becomes difficult to introduce and execute them in a deployed network. On the contrary, in evolvable networks, new communication technologies as well as novel control management policies can be adopted, deployed, upgraded easily and quickly after their initial deployment [5].

To enhance network evolvability, new protocols or solutions should be tested thoroughly via simulation or experimental testbeds before real deployment to identify potential problems and eradicate errors as well as verify protocol functions [26]. However, these experimental testbeds also have limitations compared to real field-level deployment scenarios. Hence, with the emerging network virtualization technologies, isolating unique network resource entities to verify these new protocols or solutions under real environments, will greatly facilitate the innovation process.

div.head: B. Characteristics of UWSNs
div.p: UWSNs have unique characteristics as they are deployed in harsh underwater environments. More specifically, we lay out the primary characteristics in terms of applications, communication technologies, deployment architectures, network communication devices and software protocols, the description of each is given as follows.

1) UWSN Applications: UWSNs can be applied to a broad range of applications, which can roughly be classified in terms of environment monitoring, exploration, disaster prevention, assisted navigation and maritime military applications [1], [27], [43]. In environment monitoring, the capability of remote sensing enables real-time ocean and water quality monitoring (e.g., temperature, electrical conductivity, ammonium nitrogen, dissolved oxygen, pH, turbidity, salinity, bacterial and pollution materials) feature.

Other underwater monitoring applications can protect harbor, coastline and commercial products/facilities (e.g., oil rig platforms, hydroelectric equipment and fisheries). For example, UWSNs can be used for monitoring the health of underwater assets (e.g., submarine pipelines of oil, gas or water and communication cables), exploring the biological ecosystems of the deep ocean and sea bed as well as investigating marine life (e.g., fish, underwater animals and coral reef), detecting underwater natural resources of seabeds (e.g., oil and minerals), monitoring disaster activities continuously to establish early warning systems (e.g., volcano, earthquake, tsunami and flood), and exploring and mapping the ocean seabed floor.

UWSNs can be used for assisted navigation while traveling via ships, boats, vessels, AUVs or even divers, especially in complex underwater environments. As sensors are deployed in dangerous navigation areas, when vessels or vehicles pass these areas, sensors can communicate and guard them successfully to get through those dangerous areas [44].

The efforts of incorporating UWSNs into maritime military operations have significantly propelled the development of UWSNs. For example, the most well-known underwater maritime network Seaweb can be traced back to 1995, which was primarily designed for the applications of US Navy [45]. As abundant ocean environment information (e.g., ocean temperature, electrical conductivity, salinity, turbidity, waves, currents and tides) greatly enhance naval warfare information capabilities in terms of command, communication and control, UWSNs can be operated as distributed autonomous monitoring systems that can provide real-time monitoring information of the ocean warfare region [46].

UWSNs can also be deployed in the targeted area as a tactical surveillance system to detect and track sea surface, subsurface intruders, submarines as well as mines [27], [33], [47]- [50]. In these surveillance networks, in addition to fixed underwater sensors, unmanned autonomous vehicles can communicate collaboratively to build underwater mobile sensor networks in order to execute more complex surveillance or target tracking missions [51], [52]. Apart from these traditional military missions of UWSNs, in the future naval war, the weaponized unmanned underwater vehicles can even automatically construct a swarm weapon system to carry out predefined military attack operations in a cooperative manner [53].

2) Underwater Wireless Communication Technologies: The harsh underwater environment poses a great challenge when developing underwater communication systems in spatially and temporally varying propagation media [55]. Currently, there are several underwater wireless communication technologies (e.g., acoustic, optical and EM), which can be applied to UWSNs [4]. Although each of these technologies has their pros and cons, these technologies can be combined together to fully exploit their potentials. In the following, we illustrate some characteristics of each technology, and the main characteristics of the complementary communication technologies are summarized in Table I.

-Underwater Acoustic Communication: The acoustic communication is the primary technique used in underwater communication systems currently, which has many unique characteristics (e.g., low transmission speed, high delay, limited bandwidth, low data rate, worse multi-path effect, worse doppler spread, noisy environment, high bit error rate (BER) and high spatially and temporally varying channel). Although acoustic waves have the advantage of long transmission range in water, its propagation velocity is extremely slow, which is approximately 1500 m/s in the ocean [4]. Consequently, acoustic communication has a high propagation delay (about 0.67 s/km), which is five orders of magnitude higher than terrestrial RF communication.

Even worse, the acoustic speed is not constant but varies with ocean temperature, salinity and pressure, which lead to a variable sound propagation delay. Hence, underwater acoustic communication experiences high and variable propagation delay, and spatially and temporally varying channel. Underwater acoustic channel also suffers intermittent connectivity, i.e., the communication path is temporarily lost due to ocean turbulence, currents, or movement of sensor nodes [18], [56]. Moreover, underwater acoustic channel has a limited bandwidth and low data rate as the absorption of sound propagation is severely dependent on both acoustic signal frequency and transmission distance [8]. Since high frequency suffers greater attenuations than low frequency, the optimal frequency range for kilometre-range transmission is narrowed to below one hundred kHz [43].

The spatially varying speed of sound, which is mostly related to depth, gives rise to refractions of acoustic signal (in shallow water, between ocean surfaces and sea bed). Consequently, it results in multiple propagation paths between the source point to the receiver point with varying delays. Doppler spread arises from both the slow speed of sound and the fluctuations of path length of signal transmission, which is caused either by the movement of sensors (e.g., AUVs and UUVs) or by the fluctuations of sound that scatter sea surface [55]. Underwater acoustic environment is also noisy especially in shallow waters. The sources of ambient noise include natural and man-made noise, such as bubbles, tides, rain, storms, ships, marine animals, ocean plant machinery operations, offshore drilling, etc. The overall noise level is generally frequency-dependent which should be considered when choosing operating frequency for acoustic modems [4].

-Underwater Optical Communication: As optical technology on light-emitting node (LED) has been greatly advanced recently, more attentions are paid to develop a high bandwidth underwater wireless communication technique, which is considered as a complementary solution to mitigate the limitations of traditional acoustic communication. Therefore, it can be used for short-range, high data-rate tasks such as real-time video transmission or short-term bulk data retrieval. Overall, with this technology, the communication range is within one hundred meters, but transmission delay is very low and the data transfer rate can reach several tens to several hundreds Mbps or even Gbps [25], [57], [58].

Underwater optical communication is affected by turbidity of ocean, light scattering and background ambient light noise. Moreover, the optical communication requires a line-of-sight link to operate in point-to-point style, i.e., two communication nodes need to be precisely aligned. This is because the communication light has narrow divergence angles, and thus produces optical beams with high directivity. However, the misalignment of optical communication is unavoidable, especially with mobile sensor nodes [59]. To reduce the requirement of strict alignment, the scattering property of light diffusion at the receiver side can be utilized. Another method is to design quasi-or omni-directional optical front-end to improve alignment efficiency [60].

Currently, several commercialized underwater optical modems are available. For example, BlueComm 200 is capable of transmitting high speed data ranging from 2.5 to 12.5 Mbps, and the transmission range is up to 150 m in moderate to low turbidity dark water environments. Another type of modem BlueComm 5000 has higher data rate which can reach up to 500 Mbps but with a maximum communication range at 7 meters [61].

-Underwater EM Communication: As the maximum attainable data rates of acoustic communication are limited between tens of kbps to hundreds of kbps [62], both EM and optical communications are envisioned as complementary technologies that compensate the weakness of acoustic communication [25], [63]. Generally, EM is suitable for short-range communications with high data transmission rates ranging from several Mbps to tens of Mbps [64]. EM communication has several advantages compared to acoustic communicating systems, such as immunity to acoustic noise and bubbles, being unaffected by water depth and turbidity and non-lineof-sight communication. In addition to these, EM waves can communicate across boundaries (e.g., water-to-air, airto-water, water-to-seabed and seabed-to-water) [63]. These unique characteristics can be used for interesting applications. For example, submerged sensor nodes can communicate with surface sink nodes, or shore sink nodes directly, or can collect sensed data from the submerged sensors directly using near ocean surface UAVs.

EM technology also has a property of multi-path communication even through seabed, which makes it suitable to operate Non-line-of-sight, cross boundary communications near the shore and sea floor. This feature can be used to construct wireless navigation assistant systems to guide AUVs or ROVs to expected sites based on the gradient magnitude of EM signal, e.g., the docking sites for recharging or high speed data retrieval. A major drawback of this technology is that it requires relatively bulky antennas, and hence it is susceptible to EM interference.

3) Deployment Architectures: UWSNs are deployed in the oceans, rivers, lakes or even fish ponds. Depending on specific applications, the versatile architectures of UWSNs can be categorized into a variety of types (e.g., static or mobile networks, two-dimensional or three-dimensional networks, seabed or surface networks and hybrid deployed networks). We briefly describe them as follows.
-Static Deployment: The static networks can be deployed on the surface of the ocean or near the sea floor on sea-bed. These can be deployed based on 2-D or 3-D architecture [22].

-Mobile Deployment: Mobile networks can be deployed in the ocean with AUVs, UUVs, or ROVs based on 3-D architecture. They also can be deployed on the ocean surface moved with ocean currents, or with USVs on the sea surface based on 2-D architecture.

-Hybrid Deployment: Aside from static or mobile networks, complex heterogeneous underwater networks can be deployed both on the sea surface, in the ocean space and on the seabed. The sensors in the network can be static or mobile, or even with AUVs, UUVs, ROVs and underwater gliders [65]. The heterogeneous devices should be operated cooperatively to perform sophisticated tasks (e.g., maritime military surveillance and monitoring).

4) Communication Devices and Software Protocols: Underwater communication devices and equipment are expensive. Moreover, both the deployment and maintenance costs are very high. One sensor node usually includes a variety of sensors and a single or multi-modal communication technologies (e.g., acoustic, optical or EM). Static nodes usually use mooring line to anchor the nodes to the seabed. On the sea surface, sensor nodes can be mounted on floating buoys. Mobile sensors take the form of AUVs, UUVs, ROVs or free drifting nodes with ocean currents. As underwater devices are operated in harsh ocean environments, they are prone to failures, fouling and corrosion [1]. Underwater devices are usually with limited battery power and it is usually difficult to change or recharge their batteries. Consequently, energy efficiency is a critical metric in the design of network protocols [66]. Mobile nodes, such as AUVs, UUVs, and ROVs, may have solar-powered rechargeable battery that allow those devices to operate silently underwater for months.

Generally, the traditional software protocol stack in an underwater communication device consists of a number of basic layers (e.g., physical, MAC (data link), network, transport and application) and other management control components (e.g., energy, power, localization, time synchronization, mobility and security) [1]. In UWSNs, the physical layer may have different hardware front-ends (e.g., acoustic, optical and EM), which are responsible for successful transmission and reception of underwater communication modulated signals. The function of the data link layer is the reliable data transfer, which includes both the medium access control (MAC) and error control [18], [28], [29]. The network layer is responsible for discovering and maintaining routes between a source and a destination node [1], [16], [21], [30]. The transport layer is primarily for underwater flow congestion control and reliable data collection [1]. The application layer performs various application-specific tasks by utilizing sensed data as well as the underlying physical infrastructure [27].

div.head: C. Design Considerations of UWSNs
div.p: While designing UWSNs protocols, the developers should try to achieve several design objectives in terms of multiple network performance metrics as well as multiple network features as described in Section II-A. However, to develop a practical underwater communication system, three major characteristics should be kept in mind: resource constraints, complex communication environments and application diversity, as they are the key factors which influence the design of underwater protocols. Hence, although we would take all these metrics into account when designing UWSNs protocols and try our best to obtain optimized network performance, we need to tackle more real-world challenges in the design process. Consequently, under specific scenarios, it may be difficult to obtain an optimized solution that satisfies all these metrics. As these metrics can be grouped into low-level fundamental metrics (e.g., secure, reliable, efficient, robust and scalable), and high-level metrics (e.g., adaptable, evolvable and intelligent), protocol design should satisfy the low-level metrics at first. Furthermore, as there is no protocol which is suitable for all application scenarios and different applications may assign different priorities among these metrics, it is inevitable to make tradeoffs among these metrics under certain circumstances. For example, military applications may require higher priority on security compared to the ocean environment monitoring applications.

To design the architecture of a novel protocol stack for UWSNs, we need node-level, network-level and applicationlevel technologies, and should carefully consider those across multiple layers from the physical layer to the application layer [67]. Furthermore, multiple layers in the protocol stack may need to work together in order to obtain desired network performances. For example, to satisfy network reliability in terms of reliable data transfer, different strategies in multiple layers may need to work in a cooperative manner to reach that goal.

As addressing multi-layer dependent tasks in each related layer isolatedly may result in solutions with inner conflicts which lead to the degradation of overall network performance, cross-layer design is a popular approach to deal with such problems [7]. Accordingly, it requires more efforts to tackle emerging challenges of implementing cross-layer design. In addition to these basic protocol layers, other management control components, such as energy, localization, time synchronization, mobility, security and so on, are inseparable parts of the underwater communication system which need to be considered together carefully [3], [7], [43].

Utilizing software-defined technologies (e.g., SDR, CR, SDN, NFV and sensor-cloud) help designers achieve numerous network performance metrics, such as reliability, flexibility, adaptability, interoperability and evolvability. However, while adopting these available software-defined technologies, we should carefully consider the challenges of integrating these complementary technologies into a single communication system. Furthermore, although these software-defined technologies have different priorities, the overall programmability of the designed protocols should focus on satisfying required network performance metrics.

As deploying UWSNs is generally associated with high cost in terms of hardware equipment, personnel and risks [46], the designers may need simulation, emulation and fieldlevel experimentation platforms to assist the development of underwater communication systems [26], [68]. Via these welldesigned tools and platforms, the designers can conduct simulations, emulations and field experiments to validate, debug and test novel network protocols during different design phases before deploying applications in a real operating environment. This not only greatly reduces the cost of protocol development, but also shortens the system design time especially by applying integrated experimental platforms which support seamless transition from simulation, emulation to field-level testing via UnetStack, DESERT and SUNSET [69]- [71].

div.head: D. Related Work
div.p: We present related literature to this paper, and organize them into six parts as follows.

1) General and Various Specific Surveys: Several surveys overviewed general aspects of UWSNs, such as architectures, communication approaches, networking protocols, applications, challenges as well as practical solutions [1]- [4], [22], [43], [67], [72], [73]. More detailed surveys which focus on specific aspects of UWSNs, such as channel characteristics, MAC, routing, localization, multi-modal communication, testbed, deployment and application, appeared as well.

Underwater acoustic propagation channel models and their statistical characteristics are summarized in [15]. In [18], the existing underwater MAC schemes are summarized and compared, as well as the factors which affect the design of MAC protocols. Several papers reviewed underwater routing techniques [16], [21], [23]. In [16], different routing schemes are analyzed and compared in terms of resource constraints and dynamic environmental conditions. In [23], more recently developed routing approaches are overviewed, including machine learning-based routing protocols. Mobilitybased underwater routing schemes are overviewed in [21] as well.

Localization algorithms are overviewed in [17], [19], [24]. These surveys classify the existing localization methods into different groups. For example, range-based and range-free schemes are overviewed in [17]. In [24], the overviewed localization solutions are grouped into range-based and rangefree, static reference nodes and mobile reference nodes, and single-stage and multi-stage schemes. In [19], the localization techniques are firstly classified into centralized and distributed methods, and then each group is further divided in terms of estimation-based or prediction-based techniques. These surveys also provide performance comparison among those schemes in terms of uniform criteria, e.g., localization accuracy, speed, communication costs and coverage.

Simulation and experimental testbeds are comprehensively surveyed in [26]. Seventeen testbeds are selected and compared, which are classified into three groups in terms of lablevel, short-term and long-term field-level. It also provides guidelines to choose suitable simulation and experimental platforms according to the requirements of different applications. Deployment algorithms are comprehensively surveyed in [20], in which these algorithms are categorized into three groups based on node mobility, such as static deployment, self-adjusted deployment and movement-assisted deployment. In [27], a survey that focuses on the applications of UWSNs is carried out, in which the applications are classified into five groups in terms of monitoring activities, disaster management, military, navigation and sports.

Several survey papers have been appeared recently that focus on high bandwidth underwater optical communication technology, which is considered as a complementary option to acoustic technology [25], [57]. The paper in [57] overviewed ongoing advancements in underwater wireless optical communication (UOWC) that focuses on channel characterization, modulation schemes and coding techniques. In [25], another survey is presented which covers three aspects of UOWC, such as channel modeling, modulation and coding technologies and experimental prototypes.

2) Software-Defined Acoustic Modem: Although underwater acoustic modems have been developed for several decades, only a few literature reviews appeared recently. A comprehensive study of existing underwater acoustic modems is carried out in [74], that highlights the primary features of acoustic modems, such as modulation, carrier frequency, bandwidth, data rate, power consumption, maximum communication distance and so on. Software-defined underwater acoustic modems are reviewed in [75], which is probably the first literature review on existing software-defined technologies of both academic and industrial arena.

3) Underwater Cognitive Acoustic Networks: Several papers survey different underwater spectrum management techniques. In [76], the authors investigate the dynamic underwater spectrum sharing problems by leveraging cognitive radio (CR), and propose spectrum-aware communication networks. The opportunities and challenges of underwater cognitive acoustic networks are surveyed in [10], and it investigates the possible solutions of cognitive techniques to tackle heavily shared underwater acoustic environments and develop environmentfriendly spectrum-efficient management protocols.

4) Network Function Virtualization (NFV): NFV is a critical technology that enables SDN with highly flexible architecture [5]. A few papers reviewed the gradual development of virtualization concept in terrestrial wireless sensor networks (WSNs) [77], [78]. In [77], the potential architectures of WSNs from the perspective of virtualization and their challenges are reviewed. This further demonstrates that the corresponding algorithms can be classified into node-level and network-level types. A more detailed overview is presented in [78], in which virtualization approaches are categorized into node-level, network-level and hybrid solutions. In an underwater SDN architecture, NFV is integrated to facilitate centralized control management and the sharing of physical network infrastructure [5].

5) Software-Defined Networks: In this context, several survey papers have appeared recently for terrestrial WSNs [79]- [83]. Wireless software-defined networks are surveyed in [79], which includes four classes: wireless cellular networks, WSNs, wireless mesh networks and wireless home networks. The paper in [80] provides an overview on software-defined WSNs in terms of their applications and implementation. A survey highlighting the improvement in the management aspect of WSNs by applying the SDN concept, is presented in [82]. Comprehensive reviews in this context are carried out in [81] and [83], which summarize current work in this area and discuss design challenges, requirements and open issues. Underwater software-defined WSNs are not considered in the previous surveys, and [5] is probably the first paper which presents a complete SDN-enabled architecture towards nextgeneration underwater communication networks.

6) Internet of Underwater Things (IoUTs) and Sensor-Cloud: The IoUTs are surveyed in [13], [14]. In [13], the concept of IoUT is introduced, and the benefits and challenges are outlined. After that, the potential applications and architectures are illustrated in detail. The same idea is also surveyed in [14], and the practical applications are classified under the context of IoUT. The concept of sensor-cloud integrates resourceconstrained sensor nodes into cloud computing infrastructure to reap huge benefits, such as real-time processing and storing, online or offline data analysis, complex models extraction and so on [12]. Two research papers surveyed terrestrial sensorcloud in [84], [85]. In [84], the paradigm of sensor-cloud as well as virtual sensor configuration models, architectures, software designs and implementations are described. Furthermore, in [85], sensor-cloud is overviewed in detail including its definition, architecture and applications. This also discusses research challenges, existing approaches and future directions in this arena. In [12], an architecture for UWSNs sensor cloud is proposed for the monitoring of real-time underwater environments.

div.head: III. UNDERWATER SDR
div.p: A. Brief Overview of SDR and CR -Software-Defined Radio (SDR): In a traditional terrestrial radio system, most of its components are typically implemented in hardware (e.g., filters, modulators, demodulators and converters). Generally, these analogy modules are extremely optimized for specific applications, and hence they are hard to be changed and reconfigured [86]. To make these conventional systems more flexible and reconfigurable, on 1993, the SDR concept was first described in a published paper by Joe Mitola [87], which enables a novel paradigm shifted from inflexible hardware-based platform to reconfigurable, adaptive softwarebased architecture by replacing most of the wireless transceiver functions with software implementations in order to achieve unified RF communications and support multiple applications [88].

A sample architecture of SDR is illustrated in Fig. 3. SDR substitutes inflexible hardware with programmable and reconfigurable software-base hardware. Except for antenna, RF hardware, analog-to-digital converter (ADC) and digital-toanalog converter (DAC), all other parts (e.g., base band signal processing) are implemented in flexible digital programmingbased software that run on processors, which are easier to execute or switch between different modulation or protocol schemes in a real-time adaptative manner [89].

The goal of SDR is to increase system flexibility by moving ADC/DAC closer to the antenna in order to enhance the system with more programmable features [9]. Accordingly, most of the tasks are shifted from traditional hardware to programmable platforms, which adopt software-reconfigurable heterogeneous digital processing unit (e.g., DSPs, GPPs and field-programmable gate arrays (FPGAs)) [90]. With these programmable flexible platforms, designers are able to control the hardware, and build novel intelligent environment selfadaptive devices by configuring system parameters, such as signal bandwidth, amplitude, carrier frequency, modulation, data rate even at run-time immediately when necessary.

-Cognitive Radio (CR): One concept tightly related to SDR is CR, which can be regarded as a refined extension of SDR [9], [91]. The goal of CR is to exploit available communication resources fully by sensing environment continuously, and then reacting intelligently (e.g., transmission power selection, carrier-frequency selection and modulation scheme selection) through near-optimal decisions. A sample architecture of CR is shown in Fig. 4. Generally, several components are associated with CR, which are for sensing, analyzing, learning, decision and adaptation operations [92]- [94]. Therefore, CR is also considered as an intelligent autonomous unit that combines both SDR and a cognitive engine, together of which enable sensor nodes to have the capability of sensing communication environments, learning their changes and then reacting upon their learned results and intelligent decisions [89]. For example, a typical RF front-end, implemented in SDR, needs to sense and sample the communication channel firstly and then to choose suitable modulation scheme or a set of configuration parameters instantaneously.

div.head: B. The Potential Benefits of Applying SDR to UWSNs
div.p: The principles of both SDR and CR can be applied to underwater networks to increase node-level programmability in terms of flexibility, adaptability, reconfigurability and agile cognitivity. Jones was probably among the first advocates to discuss how to extend and adapt those techniques to the underwater network domain [9]. In [5], SDR is proposed to be implemented in its OF-sensors via general-purpose singleboard computers in order to exploit the functionalities of GNU radio software package at physical-and MAC layer to optimize networking performance. In the case of underwater communication systems, the basic architecture of SDR and CR are as same as that of terrestrial RF systems by replacing RF antenna with underwater communication modems (e.g., acoustic, optical or EM).

Generally, these techniques can be used in UWSNs in two ways. One is to design self-adaptive reconfigurable underwater SDM. The other way is to design underwater cognitive networks with the advanced underwater spectrum management features [10]. When SDR is incorporated to UWSNs, several benefits can be derived from these novel paradigms, which are summarized as follows.

-Adaptability and Flexibility: One primary goal of underwater software-defined devices is to increase their adaptability and flexibility to cope with the complex and rapidly changing underwater communication environments [8]. The SDR paradigm enables underwater acoustic modems as selfadaptable and cognitive programming devices by reconfiguring its hardware communication parameters, switching between different operational modes or communication techniques and selecting from different transmit power levels.

Accordingly, these programmable devices not only satisfy different application requirements dynamically, but are able to make real-time intelligent decisions adaptively to spatially and temporally varying underwater communication environments in order to achieve optimized performance. Since there does not exist a typical and common underwater communication environment, a designed communication system may work perfectively in one environment but may not work well in another operating environment [55]. Consequently, adaptability and flexibility features help the systems operate effectively with different deployment environments.

-Interoperability: SDR is the node-level software-defined technique, which aims to realize programmable and reconfigurable physical-and MAC layer. Therefore, SDR offers better opportunities for designers to resolve interoperability among different off-the-shelf modems made by different vendors, which have closed architecture and communication stacks. Leveraging SDR-based programmable and reconfigurable underwater modem, high level protocols (e.g., network-and application layer) can reconfigure network parameters (e.g., operating frequencies and modulation schemes) freely at realtime, and can adjust the degree of interoperability to enhance the cooperation of sensor nodes dynamically.

-Rapid Prototyping: Leveraging SDR, most of the traditional functionalities (e.g., signal detection, error correction, modulation and demodulation) of hardware-based modems can be replaced by software-based implementation. Thereby, SDR provides a great support for researchers to conveniently and easily construct versatile programmable and reconfigurable rapid prototyping experimental platforms suitable for various scenarios, which can be used to test and verify novel protocols in relatively low cost [26].

-Cognitive Spectrum Utilization: Underwater acoustic communication spectrum has several unique features such as scarcity, heavily shared with both ocean animals or other underwater communication systems. With CR, underwater communication devices have the capability to re-program and reconfigure physical-and link layer. More importantly, it also has a cognitive engine which enables devices to tackle more complex tasks such as dynamic spectrum management in order to improve the efficiency of spectrum utilization.

-Easy Update: In a SDR-based underwater device, major traditional hardware-based components are replaced by programmable software. This characteristic of the SDR-based devices makes it easier to upgrade them with newly developed algorithms via software update to improve network performance [69], [95].

-Intelligent Node: The architecture equipped with both SDR and CR perfectly integrates the operations related to sensing, decision making and action together. As a consequence, underwater sensor nodes evolve towards intelligent nodes. Such intelligent underwater devices are highly adaptive with their operating environments, and hence can perform complex tasks intelligently. Apart from that, the cognitive engine equips a node with learning ability, i.e., to learn from the continuous interactions with varying environments and differentiated application requirements through the process of analysis, summarization and adjustment. With the huge advancements of artificial intelligence (AI) in recent years, the cognitive engine is incorporated with AI-based algorithms (e.g., machine learning, reinforcement learning as well as deep learning) to enhance node intelligence.

div.head: C. Typical SDR Platform of USRP/GNU Radio
div.p: Although there are several commercial SDR platforms available for radio frequency (RF) research currently, the free open source GNU radio and open hardware platform front-end USRP demonstrated huge potential in terms of convenience to researchers [96]. Generally, a typical SDR platform may need a powerful host PC to conduct digital baseband processing tasks via signal processing software libraries or tools such as GNU Radio, LabVIEW, MATLAB/Simulink and so on. In such a SDR platform, USRP acts as a radio front-end receiving or transmitting signals for its ADC or DAC modules, which is connected with the host personal computer (PC) and its software tools.

-GNU Radio [97]: An open-source software development toolkit, called GNU Radio, is one of the most popular SDR frameworks. It has a comprehensive library for hardware-independent modulation schemes and signal processing modular-based blocks written in C and C++ (e.g., modulators, amplifiers and filters) [96]. In GNU Radio, a visualization flowgraph tool, which is implemented in Python, is used to connect different basic building blocks via continuous stream of flows. Accordingly, designers are also allowed to create new user-defined signal processing blocks using those primitive basic blocks in the library, and then add them into the existing library to build or verify novel complex radio systems [8].

-USRP [98]: The pure software tool GNU radio requires minimal RF front-end hardware to build real-world SDR systems. Developed by Ettus Research and National Instruments, USRP is one popular inexpensive complementary reconfigurable hardware, which is coupled with GNU Radio closely. USRP is composed of a mother board and a range of daughterboards. The mother board, which contains ADC, DAC, FPGA and so on, is connected to a host computer that runs the GNU Radio. The daughter boards operating in various frequency bands serve as the RF front-ends to receive or transmit radio waves. Currently, USRP has four different types for different operations, such as Bus series, Network series, Embedded series and X series [98]. Note that, the Embedded series are especially designed for portable and battery operated outdoor embedded systems, which can be deployed on a Xinlinx Zynq SOC including an ARM microcontroller.

-USRP/GNU Radio Structure: Just as in the research area of terrestrial RF, USRP is also deeply integrated to GNU Radio in order to adapt to underwater channels, which is the most popular software-defined modem platform for its openness as well as free access [96]. Typically, it is hard to run SDR on embedded systems because of the computational complexity (e.g., GNU radio/USRP 210), which usually requires a host PC to run on [99]. However, the advancement of the technology makes them portable stand-alone SDR platforms currently without requiring a host PC to run on (e.g., USRP E310 does not need a host computer) [99].

Since most of the commercial SDR platforms are designed to satisfy the requirements of RF terrestrial communications, when adapting those platforms to underwater domain, researchers should resolve several challenges. For example, most of the underwater acoustic modem frequencies are confined to less than a hundred kHz, whereas several commercial SDR platforms have limited frequency range which is not suitable for underwater research (e.g., the frequency range of USRP E310 is from 70 MHz to 6 GHz) [76]. Although the frontend provides frequency bandwidth from DC to 30 MHz after adding a daughter board in USRP, which can be used for underwater research, the lack of power amplifier leads to limited experimental communication range [8].

div.head: D. Software-Defined Modem (SDM)
div.p: Underwater acoustic modems are the major components of UWSNs, and the essential parts of underwater sensor nodes or underwater mobile devices, which integrate sensing, data transceiving and even moving functionalities together. The acoustic modems are responsible for network communication, such as receiving or transmitting data in a wireless manner [100]. The ongoing underwater network research is tightly dependent on two types of modems, which could be classified into two groups. One group focuses on developing MAC-, network-, or application layer protocols based on available commercial modems, while the other group concentrates on developing new experimental modems and relevant protocols [8]. Currently, commercially available underwater modems are equipped with fixed hardware and proprietary closed software, and hence most of them are hard to modify and reconfigure. On the contrary, as SDR exhibits favorable characteristics in controlling fixed hardware, researchers extend the paradigm into SDM to design user-programmable, softwarereconfigurable intelligent hardware [75].

Accordingly, with these software-defined programmable hardware, designers are able to address the challenging underwater communication channel by modifying hardware parameters in the physical layer (e.g., signal processing chain, error correction codes, modulation or demodulation), MAC layer, or even in network layer (e.g., algorithms or protocols), in order to obtain optimal communication performance [101], [102].

Driven by the demand of more reliable, reprogrammable and reconfigurable underwater acoustic modems, a great deal of research efforts have been dedicated to the development of SDMs. In this section, we select typical SDMs including both research-oriented and off-the-shelf commercial modems to highlight the development history and other functional features in this domain, as depicted in Table II. Although there are many software-defined underwater acoustic modems [103], [104], limited by our paper, we select 13 typical modems to illustrate. For more detailed information of software-defined modems, please refer to [74], [75].

1) Hardware and Software Framework: SDM operates through both software and programmable hardware, in which some typical hardware functionalities (e.g., mixers, filters, amplifiers, detectors, modulators and demodulators) are implemented in software that run on a PC or an embedded system. When we choose acoustic software and hardware to build communication systems, we need to consider the following features.

-Energy Consumption: Energy efficiency is a critical metric of underwater modems as they are operated with limited energy supply. Integrating low-power physical mechanisms into the design of modems enhances energy efficiency. For example, by enabling sleep/wake-up mode in modems, idletime power management techniques could be used to save energy [105], [106]. In addition to that, when choosing suitable reconfigurable hardware, we may consider tradeoffs among several metrics (e.g., energy consumption, computation capacity, latency, memory size, weight, package size, cost, rapid prototyping and reconfigurability) [8]. Currently, the digital processing platforms include ASICs, microcontroller, DSPs, FPGAs, GPPs and so on [90]. In [100], energy consumption among microcontroller, DSP and FPGA is compared, which confirms the benefits of energy efficiency with reconfigurable hardware.

-Reconfigurability/Programmability and Adaptability: The aspiration for reconfigurable and programmable underwater communication devices is to enhance network adaptability in order to deal with dynamic environments and satisfy various requirements of applications and test scenarios. Therefore, accessibility and reconfigurability are fundamental properties of SDMs. SDM is implemented in programmable architecture in order to provide reconfigurable and re-programmable framework that facilitates scientific underwater network research. Besides, SDM can be an intelligent cognitive device with realtime reconfigurability and adaptability (in accordance with environments) features.

-Higher-Layer Integration and Cross-Layer Design: The depth of reprogramming feature varies from modem to modem [102]. Some modems provide limited reconfigurability option only at the physical layer, while some provide the reconfigurability option in both the physical and MAC layers. For example, rModem and UANT provide the flexibility for high-level software to utilize low-level physical-and MAC layer information. Depending on the reconfigurable modem, some software-defined reconfigurable and flexible platforms are designed in favor of cross-layer paradigms that integrate lower and higher layers, e.g., PHY-, MAC-, network-and application layer.

2) Brief Review of Research-Oriented Reconfigurable Modems: The research-oriented software-defined reconfigurable modems are mainly developed by universities and underwater research centers. Most of them are research prototypes although several approaches of which are adopted or integrated into commercial modems. In the following, we highlight the reconfigurability and programmability features of the selected modems, and reveal the development history of SDMs.

The implementation of reconfigurability and programmability features can be manual or automatic based on different requirements (e.g., experiments and applications). The early developed modems have limited reconfigurability and programmability features. As the hardware and software technologies have been greatly advanced, cognitive modems and platforms have appeared. These new modems integrate emerging techniques, such as SDR and CR, to provide realtime reconfiguration via the sensing, analyzing and decision-making processes. Among the selected modems, UNET-2, SeaNet and NILUS are the first endeavors to design real-time reconfigurable and programmable cognitive modems. a) rModem: rModem is a rapid prototyping research tool [107], [119]. Its programmability feature focuses on physical layer, and it provides a JAVA-based graphical user interface (GUI) to program its hardware. Via its programmable hardware FPGA interface, the operating carrier frequency can be changed from 1 kHz to 100 kHz. The size of packets can also be changed by researchers via the GUI. It also supports simulation via Simulink that is coupled with the toolbox in MathWorks.

b) UANT: UANT is a software-defined acoustic research prototyping platform that takes USRP/GNU radio architecture, and it is probably the first open-source software-defined framework which provides programmability and reconfigurability features for both the physical and MAC layers [75]. UANT adapts TinyOS into its system to implement MAC layer functionalities [109]. Researchers can program the softwaredefined hardware with several reconfiguration options on both the physical and MAC layers. Via configurable programming, the data rate can be varied from 244 bps to 500 kpbs. Researchers can select center frequency from 0.1 Hz to 175 kHz. In [109], the scholars tested basic Aloha protocols in their platform equipped with TinyOS, and showed that the MAC layer parameters such as backoff intervals can be reconfigured. UANT also integrates TOSSIM and Linux operating system (OS) to verify and monitor application performance by reconfiguring and tuning physical and MAC layer parameters. c) UW-Buffalo: UW-Buffalo is developed by University of New York at Buffalo, and the software-defined framework is based on a commercial Teledyne Benthos modem (e.g., Telesonar SM-75) [110]. Although the original SM-75 version lacks the reconfigurability feature from the perspective of end-users, Teledyne Benthos modem provides a network application programming interface (API), called MMP, that allows researchers to implement new user-defined MAC and networking protocols to bypass the original inflexible hardcoded bond in the modem.

More importantly, MMP also provides a path to access and monitor the status of physical and logical link control (LLC) layers, as well as to control and reconfigure the modem. UW-Buffalo leverages MMP to modify the original modem by integrating Gumstix processor into it that enables a softwaredefined reconfigurable acoustic framework. Via Gumstix processor, UW-Buffalo also designs a XLC module to facilitate cross-layer design by monitoring and storing the physical and link layer status information (e.g., packet acquisition time, perceived signal-to-noise-ratio (SNR), packet error rate, contention on the channel and transmission range).

UW-Buffalo provides reconfigurability option via physical and data link layer adaptive control, such as setting the maximum number of RTS attempts, enabling positive acknowledgement, controlling acoustic data rate, configuring link layer node addresses and so on. UW-Buffalo also designed a channel emulator which can work with Matlab to conduct controlled experiments, and it also supports IPv6 protocol for the Internet access. [111]. Unlike the traditional layer-based architecture, UnetStack has a highly flexible architecture which consists of a variety of agents [69]. These versatile agents take charge of particular functions related to traditional operations of physical-, MAC-, link-, routing-, transport-or application layer. UnetStack is also highly extensible, and so new user-defined agents can be added to satisfy the requirements of customized applications. The agents in UnetStack communicate freely with any other agents in the form of request, response and notification, which greatly facilitate the sharing of system information and improve adaptability accordingly. UnetStack supports both discrete-event simulation and real-time testing, and therefore its compiled binary simulation code can be used directly by copying them into UnetStack-compatible modems (e.g., Subnero modem) for further field-level testing without any additional cross-compilation.

UNET-2 provides programmable physical, MAC as well as network layers, and hence it enables customized modems to dynamically change communication techniques in accordance with rapidly varying environments [101]. The carrier frequency can be changed up to 78 kHz, and the modulation bandwidth can also be dynamically adjusted. Furthermore, with each packet, it provides varying transmit power levels in 1 dB step interval. Researchers are also allowed to configure userdefined preambles of the modem, which indirectly controls forward error coding (FEC). Moreover, researcher can create multiple channels, e.g., a control channel and a data channel. The control channel has low-rate FEC through taking robust communication modulation (e.g., incoherent signaling scheme OFDM) techniques into account, while the data channel has high-rate FEC with coherent signaling scheme OFDM. The parameters of those modulation schemes (e.g., packet length and number of carriers) can all be dynamically controlled. e) SeaNet: Several versions of SeaNet appeared, namely SeaNet G0, G1 and G2. SeaNet G0 (2014) is based on GNU/USRP architecture, and intends to provide real-time physical layer adaptively while coping with rapidly time varying channels [95]. To realize real-time adaptation capability, SeaNet G0 needs an extra low data rate robust feedback link to synchronize between the receiver and the sender. This feedback link is based on B-CSS modulation scheme, which has a variety of desired characteristics, such as reliability, lowdata rate, and resilience to underwater doppler and multi-path effects. Leveraging benefits of both SDR and CR, SeaNet provides real-time reconfiguration facility via sensing, analyzing and decision-making processes.

SeaNet offers three types of real-time reconfigurability options which are connected to the user-defined cogni-tive decision-making operation [8]. First, SeaNet can jointly choose different modulation schemes (i.e., BPSK and QPSK) and error correction coding rates to meet preset BER based on signal-to-interference-plus-noise-ratio (SINR) of received packets dynamically. Second, SeaNet supports seamless dualmode switching operation between ZP-OFDM and DS-SS at run-time. Third, in order to maximize pre-detected SINR of receivers, SeaNet offers online code-waveform adaptation facility by adjusting the length of channel wave-form based on varying communication environments.

In 2015 and 2016, SeaNet released new versions as SeaNet G1 [112] and SeaNet G2, respectively [113]. SeaNet G1 discards GNU/USRP architecture of G0 as that architecture is bulky and runs on a host-PC. Instead, SeaNet G1 incorporates a compact and energy-efficient ARM Cortex-M4 based USB development board, i.e., Teensy 3.1 [120]. Compared to SeaNet G0 which provides reconfiguration option in the lower layers, SeaNet G1 extends it to the higher layers (e.g., MAC-, network-and application layer). Its software stack is modularbased, and supports cross-layer reconfiguration.

SeaNet G2 aims to construct high speed software-defined modems that are suitable for short distance communication. In a sea trial with a 10 m horizontal communication link, the data rate can reach up to 522 kbps. This version of SeaNet incorporates a more powerful architecture, including a Xilinx Zynq-7020 Board (FPGA+ARM Cortex-A9). Furthermore, SeaNet G2 uses re-programmable hardware FP-GA to execute the functionalities of both intensive physical layer and time-critical MAC layer, which essentially result in reconfigurable physical layer, low processing latency and high-speed data transfer. With the reconfigurable FPGA, it further provides physical re-programmability features (e.g., modulation and coding scheme selection, power control and switching among different physical layer schemes). SeaNet G2 is also considered as an example of the architecture for a modular-based software. The modules of this modem are installed on Linux OS. Internet functionality, based on IPv4 and IPv6, is achieved in SeaNet G2 via an adaptation module. An innovative acoustic energy transfer module is designed and experimented in SeaNet G2 that utilizes acoustic wave energy to recharge underwater nodes in a wireless manner [121], [122].

f) NILUS: NILUS softModem is based on a generalpurpose architecture (e.g., Dual-Core ARM Cortex-A9 board) [75], [102]. With this powerful architecture, the softwaredefined stack runs on GP processors under an OS (e.g., Linux). This allows end-users to use standard high-level languages such as C or C++ for programming the modem. These languages are easier than other languages that require specific skills and knowledge, and this eventually shortens the development duration. NILUS is integrated to ns2-based DESERT framework [123], and it is probably the first modem with high level flexibility by using high-level programming languages without emphasizing the underlying hardware details. However, this flexibility comes at the cost of devoiding energy-efficient DSP and FPGA, which incur higher energy consumption and a longer wakeup time. Hence, there is a tradeoff to balance between energy consumption and devel-opment complexity. The future version of NILUS is expected to incorporate reconfiguration capabilities (e.g., autonomous protocols switching, data-rate changing and so on) [75].

g) SeaModem: SeaModem is a low-cost softwaredefined modem for underwater communications in shallow water [124]. SeaModem provides a wide range of reconfiguring and programming options in terms of the number of modulation tones, error detection and correction algorithms and transmission power. By choosing the number of MFSK modulation tones (e.g., 2, 4 or 8), the data-rate can be changed according to 750, 1500 and 2250 bps. The transmission power can be adjusted up to 40 W. SeaModem is integrated to SUNSET framework, which supports seamless simulation, emulation and field-level testing [71]. It is also integrated to JANUS, and a dual-PHY modem is experimented that aims to improve network interoperability among heterogeneous underwater devices [125].

3) Commercial Modem Design: The commercial modems on the market have some different features compared to research-oriented modems. A comparative study in terms of different performance metrics, such as modem energy consumption, data rate, bandwidth and maximum transfer distance, is conducted in [74]. Although most of the commercial modems have rigid hardware architecture, several vendors began to open part of their APIs for end-users to access and modify the parameters of lower layers directly. For example, Teledyne Benthos developed a modem management interface, called MMP, on SM-75 modem for end-users to implement novel user-defined protocols [126].

a) AquaSeNT: AquaSeNT is initially developed by the University of Connecticut, and then licensed and launched as a commercial modem [115], [127], [128]. AquaSeNT is an OFDM modem based on DSP with carrier frequency of 24 kHz, and integrated with SeaLinx framework [129]. To deal with the fast varying channel, an adaptive modulation and coding scheme is designed to improve the self-adaptability feature of the modem [130]. Five distinct transmission modes with varying data rates are implemented by mixing different modulation schemes (e.g., QPSK, BPSK and 16-QAM) and code rates (e.g., 1/2 and 3/4). The modem switches among different modes according to some effective SNR, which is computed via the channel estimation and decoding technique.

b) Subnero: The software-defined modem, Subnero, is based on agent-based UnetStack that combines computing platforms such as Linux SBC, DSP and FPGA [116]. Its typical carrier frequency is about 27 kHz, and the communication range is about 2 -3 km. Subnero supports multiple acoustic links simultaneously, such as both a low-rate control link and a high-rate data link. The typical data rate of a control link is about 500 bps, and data link is about 2 -10 kbps. Subnero provides the options to program multiple layers, and hence allows end-users to adjust and reconfigure carrier frequency, preambles, modulation schemes (e.g., PSK-OFDM, incoherent OFDM and FH-BFSK) and error correction code rates [75]. As Subnero is based on UnetStack, it is also an extensible modem where user-defined features can be added via its simulators.

c) Develogic: Develogic released Hydro-Acoustic HAM series on 2010, and it is among the first commercial modems to open up their closed architecture to end-users for the purpose of control and reconfiguration [117]. HAM is based on TI DSP, and the carrier frequency can be changed from 2.5 kHz to 70 kHz via this. It also offers accessibility and reconfiguration facilities for physical, data link and network layers. HAM provides end-users two options to reprogram the modem. The first option is suitable for the configuration of light parameters by connecting modem to a programming terminal via either an acoustic wireless link or a wired link. With this option, parameters of adaptive signal processing control, packet retransmit control, node addresses and identification, can be reprogrammed conveniently and verify protocols quickly. The second option is used for complex reprogramming, such as adding new functionalities to the modem (e.g., modulation schemes and error correction schemes) or upgrading old protocols. This needs a programming tool (e.g., Texas Instrument's Code Composer Studio and GNU) to reprogram the modem's software via C/C++ language, and then compile the software into a new hex firmware file uploaded into the modem.

d) Evologic: EvoLogics released the WiSE modem series on 2012, which provides open environments for end-users to control and customize the modem [118]. WiSE is with sweep-spread carrier, and based on DSP and FPGA hardware. A Linux virtual machine is run on the hardware of WiSE modem. When WiSE is integrated to GNU radio, it can be re-programmed via scripting languages [131]. WiSE is compatible to multiple simulation frameworks (e.g., NS-2/NS-Miracle based DESERT [70], SUNSET [71] and UnetStack [69]), which brings convenience to simulate, emulate and then deploy the same software to modem for further field-level testing. It also adopts data link layer protocol D-MAC into its firmware [132].

4) Multi-Modal Modem Design: The acoustic modem is still the primary underwater communication technology for long-range and reliable data transfer. However, a wide range of underwater applications demand high-speed data transmission with short distance to carry out tasks such as retrieving sensed data or transferring video images in a very short time [133]. Besides, underwater EM and optical communication technologies have been developed rapidly in the recent years. Accordingly, multi-modal modems can utilize these complementary methodologies jointly with the expectation to improve overall network performance. At the same time, both underwater open architecture SDOAM and the first international standardization physical modulation coding scheme JANUS support multimodal modems [114], [134]. In the following, we provide the description of two typical multi-modal modems.

a) AquaNodes: AquaNodes is probably the first experimental multi-modal SDM [108]. It uses 532 nm light for optical communication that ranges from 2.2 m to 8 m with a cone angle varying from 30 to 90 degrees. The maximum data rate can reach up to 320 kbps with a range about 2 m, and the acoustic link can reach up to 330 bps with a maximum of 400 m range. Researchers can adjust duty cycle of the hardware, and program both data sampling frequency and communication rate accordingly.

b) FMM: In [99], a flexible and modular-based multimodal modem, which is denoted as FMM in this paper, is pro-posed for short-range underwater communication. Its hardware includes Xilinx Zynq-7010 processor with dual-core ARM Cortex-A9 as well as DSP and FPGA. The modem supports acoustic, electrical and optical front-ends. Besides, for the ease of control, it provides a wide range of reconfigurable and programmable features in terms of signal amplitude scaling, error control code, carrier frequency, data rate and modulation scheme. The modem also supports cognitive channel characterization feature [135].

div.head: 5) Standardization and Interoperability Design:
div.p: To standardize the SDM stack and enhance interoperability among modems, great efforts have been undertaken. In the following, we discuss these efforts for SDOAM and JANUS.

a) SDOAM: SDOAM is a software-defined open architecture of underwater acoustic modem, which is proposed by NATO STO CMRE [114], [136]. In this structure, many OSIlike modules are fully connected to a cross-layer framework. In each of these modules, multiple parallel protocols are managed by a policy engine, which is the intelligent component of the module. This policy engine takes charge of i) communicating with adjacent modules, ii) seamless switching between parallel protocols in its module, iii) exchanging information with cross-layer framework directly. If the cross-layer framework evolves towards a local intelligent center, SDOAM would turn into a cognitive system, which has the capability of coping with varying environments in an adaptive manner in order to achieve optimized performance.

SDOAM works well with proprietary coding schemes, and hence it can protect intellectual property by abstracting them as black-boxes with standard interfaces, which can be connected to the module. Accordingly, SDOAM supports multi-modal modem facility easily. NEMO refines SDOAM further by supporting run-time reconfigurability features and providing a bridge between underwater and above surface communication [136].
