b) JANUS: JANUS is the first international standardization effort to break interoperability barrier of underwater assets to communicate with each other freely using acoustic modems from different vendors [134]. Originally developed by NATO CMRE, JANUS has extensively been tested over the last decade with different application scenarios, and it was approved as the first international digital acoustic communication standard by NATO in March 2017. It can be adopted by both military and civilian community, and used as a global common language for undersea systems to communicate and work in a cooperative manner.

Although JANUS is basically a physical modulation and coding scheme, it does not aim to substitute the proprietary modulation schemes of existing modems forcefully. Instead, it supports a "bilingual" mechanism in order to be able to communicate via two "languages" [125]. When two JANUS-equipped underwater devices communicate, they first announce themselves on commonly-used frequency (i.e., 11.5 kHz) channel with [1,10] km effective communication range. After that, if the devices want to connect, they switch to their proprietary modulation schemes for high data-rate communication [137]. JANUS also allows a modem to have multi-modality feature [114].

6) Brief Summary of SDM: Historically, the role of underwater modem has experienced from point-to-point communications and networked communications towards softwaredefined cognitive communications. To satisfy the surging diverse application demands, the original rigid, inflexible and closed-form architecture has been substituted by reconfigurable and programmable software-defined cognitive architectures. SDMs are the fundamental blocks of the next-generation software-defined networks although there are still many significant challenges remaining in this arena.

SDR is generally a node-level software-defined technology which focuses on solving physical-and MAC layer issues of underwater modems and enabling reconfigurable, adaptable and programmable communication devices. As novel highlevel technologies have been developed, their efficient implementation depends on the underlying hardware (e.g., SDM). For example, integrating network layer paradigms such as SDN or NFV into underwater networks requires supported SDM (e.g., OpenFlow-enabled SDM). Consequently, further research is required to integrate these technologies together.

As underwater optical and EM communication technologies have become more mature recently, incorporating multiple communication technologies to develop multi-modal modems are gaining their momentum [36]. Nevertheless, exploiting the advantages of these complementary technologies fully will bring multiple benefits such as maximizing data rate, improving network robustness, and enhancing network flexibility and adaptability. Although there has been some progress on it, more research is required. For example, how to integrate multiple hardware front-ends into one single modem efficiently and how to switch between these front-ends in a seamless manner, require more efforts to figure out.

Although next-generation software-defined underwater networks bring a number of potential benefits, these networks need to run more complex protocols and more tasks are required to be carried out. The desired network performances come at the cost of putting more of the burden on energyconstrained SDMs, which require more computational capacity and energy consumption. Designing platform-independent protocols without considering details of the underlying hardware reduces development complexity although general-purpose S-DM architecture incurs higher energy consumption. Accordingly, trade-offs among energy efficiency, protocol complexity and hardware capacity are inevitable.

Further advancements of SDM depend on the development of both research-oriented and commercial SDMs. As shown in Table II, commercial modems, such as Subnerno, Develogic HAM and Evologics WiSE, are among the leading commercial SDMs. Generally, scientific-oriented research is more likely to be in favor of novel ideas. Whereas, commercial modems offer better overall performance (e.g., reliability, maximum transfer distance and energy efficiency) [74]. Therefore, establishing more cooperation among universities, research institutes and industry should significantly boost the advancements of SDMs.

div.head: E. Underwater CR
div.p: CR is an extension of SDR, and is envisioned as a promising technique that can redefine communication devices and enable them with a variety of properties (e.g., awareness, intelligence, learning ability, adaptivity, reliability and efficiency) by continuous interactions with the surrounding environment [138]. The paradigm is applied to underwater domain as underwater CR, which is defined in [139]. The goal of underwater CR is to build up intelligence by continuous interaction with operating environments to tackle challenging problems (e.g., channel uncertainties, adversary jamming and so on) by reconfiguring operation parameters (e.g., modulation strategy, transmit power and carrier-frequency).

Based on CR, underwater networks evolve towards underwater cognitive networks, the idea of which results in several interesting research topics. Note that the original concept of CR was proposed by Mitola [140]. It has a broader scope of research though it is usually referred as a promising technique that is mainly associated with the management of cognitive spectrum access [141]. In the following, we discuss two potential research areas of underwater cognitive networks, e.g., cognitive spectrum management and cognitive self-adaptive system.

1) Cognitive Spectrum Management: Inspired by the successful utilization of terrestrial radio spectrum management, CR has been extended to underwater networks for enhancing underwater spectrum efficiency [10], [76]. This spectrum management is also environment-friendly, i.e., not to interfere with other acoustic communication systems or the communication of marine animals [142]. We illustrate the development of cognitive spectrum management and cognitive self-adaptive systems as follows.

a) Underwater Acoustic Spectrum Characteristics: The utilization of underwater acoustic spectrum demonstrates several unique characteristics, which include spectrum scarcity, heavily shared spatio-temporally varying spectrum (man-made systems, marine animals) and under-utilized spectrum [10].

Generally speaking, underwater acoustic spectrum is a precious and scarce resource. The available underwater bandwidth is severely limited due to the effects of frequency-dependent attenuation, and hence most commercial underwater modems generally use a narrow bandwidth from approximately a few kHz to 100 kHz [15]. Furthermore, the spectrum is heavily shared by both man-made artificial acoustic systems (e.g., underwater network modems, sonar systems of ships, AUVs, UUVs and ROVs) and natural marine mammals (e.g., whales, dolphins, sea lions and porpoises) [10]. With the advancement of underwater networks, more man-made systems have crowded into ecosystems of marine animals aggressively. Since those underwater animals use overlapped acoustic spectrum dedicated to man-made systems for communications, echolocation and foraging [142], we should take their lives into serious consideration and design environment-friendly underwater communication systems that carefully avoid harmful interference.

Although underwater acoustic spectrum is scarce and heavily shared, due to the spatio-temporally varying characteristic, this precious spectrum is not even fully utilized especially when multiple underwater networks are deployed in the same area. The underutilized spectrum can be identified both in temporal and spatial domains [10]. The temporally under-Spectrum Sensing Spectrum Decision Spectrum Sharing Fig. 5: A sample architecture of cognitive spectrum management.

utilized acoustic spectrum can stem from the movement of users (e.g., AUVs and marine animals) or low duty cycle feature of acoustic media. The nodes, equipped with lowtraffic long-term applications (e.g., environments monitoring, offshore assets structure health monitoring), only wake-up periodically and then listen or send out sensed data. As a result, these nodes remain in the sleep mode most of the time. The spatially underutilized acoustic spectrum is usually caused by nonlinear acoustic wave propagation (e.g., shadow zones) and directional communication characteristics of marine mammals or directional acoustic modems.

b) The Dynamic Spectrum Management Procedure: This procedure takes advantages of cognitive radio to design environment-friendly and spectrum-aware communication algorithms for underwater networks while utilizing the scarce underutilized spectrum dynamically and intelligently. To realize the goal of cognitive spectrum management, underwater software-defined communication devices should have the properties, such as awareness, intelligence, reconfigurability and adaptivity, reliability and efficiency [138].

The basic concepts of cognitive cycle for terrestrial wireless systems are discussed in [143], [144], which focus on fundamental cognitive tasks, such as radio scene analysis of inference and spectrum holes, channel capacity estimation, prediction and dynamic spectrum access. Based on these ideas, a more general architecture for cognitive spectrum management in UWSNs is described in [10]. As depicted in Fig. 5, the architecture associated with cognitive spectrum management includes three primary parts (e.g., spectrum sensing, spectrum decision and spectrum sharing) which are correlated to each other.

Note that, in this framework, the implementation of both spectrum sensing and spectrum sharing procedures is based on software-defined programmable and reconfigurable communication devices (e.g., underwater modems) as those devices provide flexible reprogramming and reconfiguration options for both the physical and link layers. Overall, the research on underwater cognitive spectrum management is still in its infancy. For more detailed information in this context, please refer to [10], [76].

-Spectrum Sensing: The goal of spectrum sensing is to identify the available spectrum, detect unused spectrum holes and the changes of spectrum utilization in real time by sensing and monitoring the surrounding environment continuously. To do that, it needs a spectrum sensing scheme where suitable detection approaches (e.g., energy detectionbased, power spectrum density-based, waveform-based and cyclostationarity-based) are incorporated in accordance with the requirements of entire spectrum management [10].

-Spectrum Decision: Based on the sensed information and the available spectrum, decisions should be made intelligently by analyzing and accumulating knowledge through continuous interactions with the environment (e.g., channel state information). One output of spectrum decision is to plan spectrum distribution scheme (e.g., available spectrum allocation).

-Spectrum Sharing: The objective of the spectrum sharing is to implement dynamic spectrum access scheme by reconfiguring the operation parameters of software-defined cognitive devices (e.g., acoustic modems). Besides that, those cognitive devices should be operated in a cooperative manner. For example, to maintain harmony between the receiver and the transmitter during the process of dynamic spectrum access, a feedback channel (or control channel) should be established [145].

2) Cognitive Self-Adaptive System: CR has software-based intelligence in various aspects, e.g., awareness, analyzing and learning, decision making and reconfiguration. It is virtualized as a human "brain" with the capability of joint sensing, decision making and actuation operations intelligently. Accordingly, leveraging the cognitive intelligence of CR, cognitive self-adaptive system is designed to enhance node or network adaptivity.

In [146], an underwater cognitive self-adaptive protocol stack is proposed. As depicted in Fig. 6, it consists of several parts to sense or monitor, analyze or learn, decide or plan and execute or reconfigure. All those parts are connected through a cross-layer shared knowledge module. To provide cognitive self-adaptive capability, a famous feedback loop MAPE-K is applied to underwater domain and integrated to the architecture [147]. The MAPE-K loop enables researchers to design a cognitive policy engine, which is an intelligent agent. Being in the situation of underwater domains, this policy engine perceives surrounding environment through sensors as primitive information input. Then, the sensed data are processed while considering pre-defined requirements into account, and an optimized decision is made as an output executed by the actuators. Through the common communication environments, feedback information connects both the input and the output as a feedback-control loop, which makes the decision-making process recursive to obtain more refined results.

This cognitive architecture can be implemented on sensor nodes or on a sink node with centralized capability. It can also be implemented in a distributed manner (e.g., in the sink, cluster headers and sensor nodes) in order to virtualize itself into a single logical cognitive system. For implementing cognitive architecture in a centralized fashion (e.g., sinks and clusterheaders), more complicated machine learning techniques are required to be incorporated to the system. For example, in [146], reinforcement learning technique is integrated to the policy engine [148]. The cognitive architecture improves the self-adaptive capability of a single node as well as of the entire network. For example, when implementing cognitive architectures inside modems, the self-adaptive capability is demonstrated as realtime reconfigurable physical-and MAC layer with pre-defined metrics according to the diverse requirements of applications or varying communication environments. To verify the performance, a simulation is conducted while considering that the system is equipped with six one-hop nodes and a sink [146]. The system can automatically switch seamlessly between three MAC layer protocols (e.g., CSMA, T-Lohi and DACAP) with different metrics (e.g., packet delivery ratio, end-to-end latency and energy per bit) in accordance with the changes of dynamic communication environments.

3) Brief Summary of Underwater CR: The existing research on underwater CR primarily focuses on the development of a cognitive spectrum management system and a cognitive intelligent system. One common feature of these smart systems is that they are environment-aware and capable of reconfiguring system-level operational parameters in real-time (e.g., communication parameters, sensing parameters and actuator parameters) to carry out pre-defined tasks smartly. Under this point of view, the cognitive spectrum management systems are considered as a special use case of the cognitive intelligent systems. However, to turn this paradigm into reality for UWSNs, the researchers have to face numerous challenges [10], [76], [139], [146].

Although underwater spectrum is heavily shared while being underutilized to a great extent, in order to develop a practical environment-friendly and spectrum-efficient cognitive system, three primary parts of the system (e.g., spectrum sensing, spectrum decision and spectrum sharing) should be addressed carefully. Four key factors are identified in [10] which affect the design of a cognitive system (e.g., the narrowband response of acoustic transducer, the long preamble, the severe busy terminal problem and the highly dynamic underwater channel). Other factors (e.g., depth, distance, shipping, waves, spectrum management delay and accessibility) which affect dynamic spectrum sharing feature, are explored in [76]. How to find spectrum holes and how to change access mode in an adaptive manner to avoid possible jamming as well as frequency selective fading, are discussed in [139]. In addition to that, the importance of a stable feedback channel which is used for interactions between a sender and a receiver, is also investigated.

As acoustic attenuation is dependent on both the frequency and the transmission distance, this feature can be utilized in the development of a spectrum access scheme. Since high frequency channels suffer from higher attenuation, given that the overall location of the network is available, these channels are allocated to nodes which are closer to each other in order to maximize fairness and efficient utilization of the spectrum [141]. Having realize this fact, an effective heuristic spectrum allocation method is proposed in [149]. As an extended work of [141], only distance information of nodes is required in [150], in which an energy detection-based spectrum sensing process leverages fast Fourier transform (FFT) technique to identify available channels.

Instead of assigning fixed spectrum, dynamic assignment of frequency channel enables a more flexible cognitive system. In [145], a dynamic control channel access scheme is proposed while targeting on the avoidance of channel congestion. In this scheme, control channel can borrow more frequency band from in-band channels reserved for data traffic when control traffic becomes heavy. In another dynamic spectrum management scheme, namely RvDB, a receiver can borrow idle spectrum from its neighboring nodes to improve the efficiency of spectrum utilization [151]. A cognitive system should be not only spectrum-efficient but also environment-friendly to avoid affecting natural marine mammals in a harmful manner. Both idle spectrum and optimal transmit power allocation are jointly considered in an environment-friendly scheme [152]. In [153], a receiver-initiated spectrum management scheme namely RISM is proposed, in which marine mammals are considered as primary users [154]. In another environmentfriendly dolphin-aware scheme, namely DAD-Tx, the activities of dolphins are modeled and then integrated into the system to prevent harmful interference [142].

Derived from unique characteristics of underwater CR (e.g., sensing/analyzing, learning/decision making/ reconfiguring and acting), the cognitive intelligence can be used to design cognitive systems. In [155], cognitive intelligence is used to select accurate underwater channel model from a database in accordance with the communication environment. Another cognitive self-adaptive system, which can reconfigure its operating parameters according to the change of communication environments and application requirements, is developed in [146]. It integrates cross-layer information sharing concept, cognitive policy engine, modular-based software defined communication stack, sensors and actuators together. By leveraging reinforcement learning techniques in its cognitive policy engine, the system can automatically select suitable protocols from multiple pre-defined parallel protocols in each layer. In [156], the modular-based software defined communication stack has recently been integrated into a famous testbed platform, SUNSET.

Testing and experiments of cognitive schemes would significantly enhance the development of practical systems. However, most of the existing underwater acoustic modems lack the capability to implement cognitive networks. To meet that end, a real-time underwater cognitive testbed [135] is developed based on SeaNet G0 [95]. Via this testbed, underwater cognitive channelization experiments can be conducted in a water tank by selecting optimized waveforms adaptively in accordance with the channel conditions.

Except for the aforementioned research, other aspects of cognitive systems are also explored. For example, the interference problems and cognitive routing are investigated in [138], [157]- [159]. The dynamic spectrum sharing for sparse heterogeneous underwater networks (e.g., including AUVs) is explored in [92]. Although the research of spectrum management system currently covers all the aspects of acoustic spectrum management and great progress has been made, it is still in its infancy stage to a great extent. For example, there is no at-sea experiment reported, and more practical fieldlevel testing and evaluation results are required. As underwater multi-modal modems have the advantage of selecting different communication options, applying the cognitive paradigm to this concept requires further investigation.

div.head: IV. UNDERWATER SOFTWARE-DEFINED SENSOR NETWORKS
div.p: A. Overview of Software-Defined Networks SDN is an emerging paradigm which has successfully been applied in wired networks initially, and it was later applied to terrestrial wireless networks [79], [160], [161]. The primary goal of software-defined networks is to decouple the control plane from the data plane by separating control decisions from hardware devices (e.g., switches and routers), and therefore these devices are equipped with only simple data forwarding functionalities [81]. The separation makes the network management easier as the controllers become smarter with the global view of the entire network. Besides that, the separation also shifts the energy intensive burden from these physical devices to physically or logically centralized controllers, which are in charge of the control plane. Furthermore, to efficiently manage network devices, the controller needs to program the hardware infrastructure in order to directly control them by defining their behaviors and operations [5]. Consequently, it not only simplifies network management and improves resource utilization, but more importantly it enhances the interoperability of devices from different vendors and enables quick network innovation and evolution.

To enable a programmable data plane, a set of standards, well-defined and open APIs between the control and data plane should be designed [162]. OpenFlow is one of the most prominent interfaces of such APIs. It was originally developed for Ethernet switches and routers, which has attracted considerable attentions in both academia and industry recently [163]- [165]. The success of OpenFlow lies in the fact that most modern switches and routers are programmed with flowtables. Therefore, OpenFlow adds a number of new features to existing switches, which make them programmable without disclosure of internal secrets of these commercial devices.

A sample architecture of OpenFlow interface is shown in Fig. 7, and it is widely supported from a large number of network vendors including Cisco, HP, Juniper, Brocade, IBM, Dell, NEC and Big Switch [166]. The OpenFlow architecture consists of three parts, which are a Flow at least one action to execute (e.g., drop the flow's packets, forward the flow's packets through the network or send the flow's packets to a controller).

As the control functionality in SDN has been decoupled from the data plane, OpenFlow controller (either static controller running on PCs or logically centralized controller) takes the responsibilities of packet processing decision by updating Flow Table entries (e.g., add, delete or revise). In order to make the optimized data processing decision, the controller also needs to gather network information (e.g., network status and topology), and exchange control packets timely and efficiently with these OpenFlow switches.

The secure channel connects each switch with the remote controller to transfer command packets, and OpenFlow protocol provides an open standard interface for the controller to externally setup and update the Flow Table entries. Naturally, both the secure channel and the OpenFlow protocol are designed to guarantee the controller to reach, program and control the network intelligently with the help of a global view of the entire network.

div.head: B. Potential Benefits of Applying SDN to UWSNs
div.p: With the growing interest of applying SDN to wireless networks, researchers attempt to expand this concept into UWSNs to help tackle its inherent fundamental problems. We argue that a number of benefits can be derived from the SDNenabled adaptive solutions for UWSNs.

1) Improvement of Energy Efficiency: In SDN-enabled UWSNs, the controller is more intelligent with the global view of the entire network (e.g., node location, node residual energy, node failure and communication link quality). For example, it can select optimized routing paths to save node energy and prolong the network lifetime. Another benefit is that, because of decoupling the data plane from the control plane, the separation also relieves and shifts the energy intensive burden from normal sensor nodes to controllers, which usually reside in underwater sinks. These sinks are equipped with either solar power systems or enough battery capacity, and so the lifetime of software-defined networks can be prolonged.

2) Simplification of Network Management: UWSNs are decentralized ad hoc networks, and hence it is a complex and challenging task to manage them efficiently [167]. On the contrary, SDN enforces the centralized management aspect to allocate network resources efficiently and maximize the network throughput by leveraging the powerful and intelligent controllers. On the other hand, both network abstraction and programmable data plane make it easier to control or customize the physical resources without directly interfering their hardware operations. Other benefits derived from the centralized management include: reduced complexity of network error checking procedure and simplified network maintenance [5].

3) Enhancement of Interoperability: Establishing interoperability among heterogeneous devices from different vendors greatly facilitates the development of UWSNs by providing open standardized interfaces that exchange messages freely. However, the standardization process is slow, partially because most of the commercial vendors are reluctant to disclose their internal design in fear of losing competitive advantages in the commercial market.

The OpenFlow-based SDN paradigm provides an opportunity for researchers to bypass this problem by just installing Flow Table on existing hardware without exposing or changing internal platforms of the hardware. Therefore, a well-designed OpenFlow-based interface between data plane control plane regardless of the underlying hardware infrastructure from different vendors is expected to increase interoperability among heterogeneous devices under SDN-enabled architecture.

4) Multi-Modal Communication Support: In softwaredefined networks, the underlying hardware is accessed and controlled directly via a variety of high-level abstractions as well as through its flexible programmable data plane. Hence, it is convenient to exploit the advantages of diverse underwater communication technologies, such as acoustic, optical and EM, to satisfy specific application requirements in terms of delay, reliability and throughput [5], [133], [168].

5) Multi-Application Support: Coupled with high-level abstractions to coordinate underlying infrastructure efficiently, sensor networks are no longer application-oriented, but are application-customizable, which enable multiple applications running on one single network simultaneously to accomplish different tasks. Leveraging such advantages, researchers design OpenFlow-based APIs, and are able to develop sensing-as-aservice oriented networks for various applications by sharing the same physical hardware efficiently [5].

6) Network Evolution and Experiment Support: In conventional sensor networks, evaluation of novel protocols via experimentation is both costly and complicated as it may require access to micro-controller or even ROM of the node through reprogramming [169]. In software-defined networks, the programmable data plane provides flexibility to support multiple applications. Consequently, it is convenient to implement novel protocols as independent applications in parallel with other applications in the same network. This not only reduces the experimental cost, but also accelerates network evolution. More importantly, it provides real underwater net-work working environments which will significant enhance the effectiveness of both experiments and network evolution.

div.head: C. Challenges of SDN-Enabled UWSNs
div.p: Encouraged by the success of SDN on both wired networks and wireless networks [79], [164], [170], SDN is envisioned as a promising technology to solve inherent problems with both terrestrial and underwater WSNs [5], [80], [81], [166], [171]. However, additional functionalities need to be designed since there are a number of distinguishable characteristics between conventional wired or wireless networks and UWSNs, which raise new challenges when SDN is enabled to UWSNs [5]. The primary challenges are summarized as follows.

In SDN-enabled conventional wired or wireless networks, the programmable switches, routers or wireless APs have adequate electric power supply. On the contrary, UWSNs consist of resource-constrained sensor nodes in terms of limited battery power supply and computational capability. The paradigm of SDN decouples the control plane from the data plane, so switches act only as data forwarding devices under the control plane. However, in UWSNs, the sensor nodes not only forward data within the network, but also monitor physical environment and generate data.

Furthermore, UWSNs are typically data-centric networks, which require real-time in-network data processing (e.g., filtering out error messages and aggregating statistically measured data). Note that the performance of in-network data processing and aggregation not only reduces the number of data transmissions in order to conserve both energy and precious bandwidth, but also ensures immediate and collaborative local decision-making process. Another challenge that needs to be addressed is, UWSNs are inherently application-oriented, in which both hardware and software resources are usually vertically integrated for cross-layer optimization, which may impair the performance of software-defined networks.

Moreover, in OpenFlow-based SDN, the secure channel is used for the transmission of control messages between switches and the controllers, in which the reliable communication is guaranteed by IP-based end-to-end connections. However, the conventional UWSNs are firstly data-centric networks [6]. Furthermore, the unique characteristics of underwater acoustic communications (e.g., high bit error, long delay, spatially and temporally varying intermittent communication channel, node mobility and node failure) present challenges in implementing such secure control channel in harsh underwater environments.

div.head: D. SDN-Enabled Architecture for UWSNs
div.p: The research on SDN-enabled underwater communication networking is relatively a new research area, which is still in its infancy, although a few papers recently appeared that attempted to bring the concept of SDN into underwater communication systems [5], [172], [173]. In this subsection, we first briefly introduce the general architecture of SDN-enabled UWSNs, and then discuss various aspects of the architecture in detail.

The core idea behind the general architecture of SDNenabled UWSNs is to separate the data forwarding plane and the control plane, and to provide software-oriented hardware resources, which can be programmed and customized by the powerful logically centralized intelligent controller [5]. The general architecture of SDN-enabled UWSNs is depicted in Fig. 8, which consists of three layered planes: data plane, control plane and application plane [7]. These planes are connected to each other via a variety of APIs, in which the APIs between control plane and the data plane are called southbound APIs whereas the APIs between the control plane and the application plane are called northbound APIs.

The control plane, which resides on a logically centralized controller, is a decision maker. It is equipped with the global view of the network through the periodic collection of network state information. Utilizing these centralized knowledge, the controller is able to make intelligent decisions to configure and coordinate underlying allocated resources by customizing and updating the flow table in the data plane via a standardized southbound communication interface, such as OpenFlow-based APIs. To effectively manage the network, a variety of functions in the control plane should be designed, which include topology control, routing control, node mobility control, QoS control, traffic control, data congestion control, security control, energy control, network configuration control, spectrum control, network maintenance control and so on.

The data plane is the infrastructure plane with heterogeneous underwater static or mobile devices deployed on the seafloor, on the sea surface or in the deep ocean. Under the SDN paradigm, the date plane consists of OpenFlowbased programmable underwater sensor nodes with packet forwarding, environment sensing, in-network data processing or response capability. To fully program the data plane, each sensor node needs to be equipped with an OpenFlow-supported flow table with packets forwarding rules, defined and updated by the intelligent controller via the southbound APIs.

The application plane consists of multiple applications, e.g., that for ocean environment monitoring, marine surveillance, Fig. 9: A sample controller on the sea floor. offshore assets protection, disaster salvation and others. The implementation of these applications need both control plane and data plane to be executed via the communication of welldefined northbound and southbound APIs.

div.head: E. Control Plane Design
div.p: The control plane is the centralized control policy management center that orchestrates between the application plane and the infrastructure data plane [7]. As most of the control functions are shifted from sensor nodes to the intelligent controller, the controller becomes more critical with the growing volume of managerial and control responsibilities. In this section, we mainly discuss the issues, such as controller models, single or multiple controllers, controller placement and control traffic.

1) Controller Models: The main functionality of the controller is to manage the network by generating flow tables for the data plane. Due to the unique characteristics of UWSNs different from terrestrial wired and wireless networks, we can choose two types of control plane models, such as centralized and semi-centralized while considering the split of the managerial responsibilities among different entities [172].

-Centralized Controller Model: In the centralized control model, the network management functions are completely taken over by controllers, which relieve ordinary sensor nodes from the complex self-control management task. Hence, underwater sensor nodes are designed to execute operations controlled by remote controllers, and perform specific tasks efficiently and effectively. However, this model may only work well for small-scale networks with a limited number of sensor nodes. Furthermore, it might be difficult for sensor nodes to carry out complex tasks efficiently and cooperatively with this model, especially when faster intelligent decision making is required in response to the emergency events for delaysensitive applications.

In [172], a completely centralized control scheme is proposed for a mobile AUV network. For AUV-based applications, the number of AUVs is usually limited and even the movements of these AUVs are predictable via pre-programmed paths. Based on these facts, the authors designed a centralized control scheme to control the entire small-scale mobile network, including the planning of routing decisions, movement decisions and so on for each AUV.

-Semi-Centralized Controller Model: The original terrestrial software-defined network is naturally a software-driven network that leverages its powerful centralized intelligent controller [83]. However, when equipping this concept to underwater communication domain, an alternative model, which is called semi-centralized control model, could be taken to design semi-software-defined-networks. The reason is that UWSNs have many unique characteristics unlike terrestrial wired or wireless networks. UWSNs not only work in a harsh communication environment with limited resources such as unreliable communication channels, longer transmission delay, limited battery supply, limited computation capability, but also need to perform complex tasks which might require immediate actions in response to the emergency events besides sensing and packet forwarding decisions.

In the semi-centralized control model, the management of control function is divided between the controllers and underwater sensor nodes. Hence, it is a combination of both the centralized control and self-control, and makes a balance between centralized and distributed networks, which obtains benefits from both the centralized control and fully distributed management. Although the division of the control function management complicates the control mechanism in SDNenabled UWSNs, the tradeoff is inevitable due to the harsh underwater environment, and there is still a large space for the researchers to decide how to split the control management functions between the controllers and underwater sensor nodes.

2) Single or Multiple Controllers: In conventional UWSNs, one or more sinks are deployed in the network, which are responsible for both the data collection and network control. Hence, under the SDN paradigm, these sinks could be mapped to controllers naturally. Depending on different requirements of network scenarios, the number of controllers could be single or multiple.

-Single Controller: In a small-scale network, a single centralized controller is sufficient for the management of control functions. In [172], a single central controller architecture is proposed for small-scale underwater mobile AUV networks. As illustrated in Fig. 9, a single controller is deployed on the sea floor. One weakness of the single centralized controller is, it is vulnerable to security attacks. Another drawback is that, as network scales, the increased number of sensor nodes cause a large amount of control traffic and a higher control delay. This causes a communication bottleneck in the controller that in turn decreases the efficiency of network management.

-Multiple Controllers: The design associated with multiple controllers helps to improve network scalability in addressing the increased control communication overhead especially with large-scale networks. Generally, these geographically distributed controllers require to form a logically centralized controller across the entire network. However, the number of controllers and their placement have a significant impact on the effectiveness of these controllers.

To reduce control overhead and simplify controllers management, a hierarchical controller architecture can be used, in which a logically centralized controller is realized by many distributed local controllers. Accordingly, each local controller Fig. 10: A sample deployment scenario of a surface controller. manages a cluster which is formed by either geographical location or other metrics. In such an architecture, tradeoffs may need to be made in terms of the centralized control or the distributed control. For example, local controllers should actively respond to the requirements of cluster network management without incurring too much overhead for remote controllers.

fully benefit from such logically centralized controller, these controllers need to synchronize periodically themselves to exchange and share the global network information, which require reliable and effective inter-controller communications.

3) Controller Placement: In three-dimensional ocean space, the deployment scenarios of controllers can be both stationary and mobile. When controllers are stationary, they can be placed on the sea surface mounted on floating buoys, on the sea floor or in the deep oceans. As illustrated in Fig. 10, a single controller is deployed on the sea surface, whereas in [5], a multi-controller deployment scheme is proposed for the sea surface. The benefits of deploying controllers on the sea surface are twofold. First, these controllers can utilize solar power to support long-term ocean operations. Second, multiple physically distributed surface controllers can leverage the high speed radio communication systems to form logically centralized controllers with higher bandwidth and shorter delays.

The stationary placement of controllers has a dramatic impact on the network performance. However, the optimal solution to find the placement of multiple controllers is still an open NP-hard problem [174]. Furthermore, one shortcoming of the stationary deployment of controllers is that it might lead to the unbalanced control load among the controllers as well as the sensor nodes. The authors in [5] also pointed out that the stationary placement of controllers may result in the degradation of control plane performance due to the changes of data traffic pattern with the ever-changing communication environment.

An alternative solution to the stationary deployment of controllers is to deploy a single or multiple mobile controllers. These mobile controllers can be deployed on the sea surface with USVs or ASVs as well as deployed in the deep ocean with AUVs. As these mobile controllers are usually powered by rechargeable battery units, they support long-term missions which can last several months. Aside from that, these mobile controllers can also serve as mobile sinks that retrieve sensed data [175].

To perform multiple tasks effectively, these AUVs can be equipped with multi-modal communication technologies, such as acoustic, optical and so on. Acoustic links can be used for long-range and lower data rate control channel, whereas optical links can be used for short-range and high speed data retrieval purpose. Since the transmit power is usually more expensive than that of the receive mode (e.g., typical receive power of the WHOI micro-modem is about 80 mW, but transmit power is 10 W), AUVs can broadcast control messages while underwater sensor nodes just passively listen so as to reduce their energy consumption [176].

When deploying multiple mobile controllers in a given network to cover three-dimensional deployment space under multiple criteria, the number of controllers, as as AUVs path planning to be resolved via optimization algorithms [177]. Another problem with mobile controllers is its long time delay as AUVs usually travel at relatively slow speed. For example, the speed of one type of REMUS is in [1.5-2.9] m/s range with which it consumes around W level of power [26]. Under such slow speed, in large-scale networks, mobile controllers experience longer control delays.

4) Control Traffic: To control and manage the underlying resources of the data plane, the controllers need to communicate with the sensor devices via southbound APIs, which incur additional control communication overhead using either out-of-band control channels or in-band control channels. We discuss them in detail as follows.

-Out-of-Band Control: Just as the secure channel in wired SDN-enabled networks, an out-of-band control channel can be reserved and dedicated only for control traffic in UWSNs. For example, while deploying multiple controllers on the sea surface with floating buoys as described in [5], low power wide area technologies such as NB-IoT, LoRa or other longrange RF wireless communication technologies could be used for one-hop out-of-band control traffic [178]- [180].

Except for the usage of RF to form control channels above the ocean surface, other communication links could be chosen as dedicated channels for the management of control traffic especially when underwater sensor nodes are equipped with multiple communication technologies (e.g., optical, acoustic or EM). For example, we can use the long-range acoustic link dedicated for the communication of underwater control traffic to realize one-hop out-of-band control, whereas other communication links for the transmission of multi-hop data packets. The paper in [172] proposed a scheme to deploy a centralized underwater controller using one-hop long-range acoustic communication links to reach AUVs in the network. Instead of benefiting from such long-range acoustic communications, its shortcomings, such as high propagation delay and limited bandwidth, should be considered carefully when designing control protocols in terms of minimum delay, maximum throughput and congestion control.

-In-Band Control: Different from out-of-band control where a separate channel is dedicated for control messages, both control traffic and data traffic must share the same channel via in-band control, which impose significant challenges in terms of uncertain wireless link quality and possible traffic congestion. Compared to the traditional terrestrial wired or wireless networks, in which SDN is originally developed, efficient management of UWSNs generally requires the exchange of more control messages. Thereby, special considerations should be taken to reduce control traffic, and relieve the burden of communication channels while designing in-band control solutions. In addition to that, it is worth noting that the number of controllers as well as their placement in deployed networks also have a great impact on the overall control overhead.

div.head: F. Design of Data and Application Planes
div.p: The data plane primarily consists of OpenFlow-based programmable underwater sensor nodes, which can forward packets, monitor environments, generate packets, or even perform appropriate actions according to the instructions made by the control plane. To implement these predefined tasks, each sensor node should include multiple layers or modules (e.g., physical, MAC and other layers). To program the data plane, each sensor node requires to install an OpenFlow-supported flow table with a set of packet forwarding rules, which are defined and updated by the intelligent controller via the southbound APIs.

An OpenFlow-enabled programmable underwater sensor node, OF-sensor, is proposed in SoftWater [5]. OF-sensor consists of four parts: Wireless Hypervisor, OpenFlow-supported Flow Table, Software-Defined Radio and Multiple hardware front-ends (e.g., acoustic, optical or EM). A node-level resource scheduler Wireless Hypervisor can create multiple virtual OpenFlow sensors, namely V-OF-sensors, that operate on different protocols or communication technologies within the same physical OF-sensor. The OpenFlow-supported flow table defines routing or control decisions in terms of sets of flow entries for an OF-sensor to handle packets, which are controlled or modified by the controllers. The PHY-and MAC layer functions are in the form of software, and so OF-sensors can easily exploit the advantages of SDR to reconfigure softwarized PHY-and MAC layer resources for the optimized performance (e.g., reconfiguration of modulation, demodulation of PHY-layer, frequency, code of MAC layer). OF-sensors also support multiple communication hardware front-ends (e.g., acoustic, optical or EM). Along with the softwarized PHY-and MAC layer, it is convenient for OFsensors to choose and reconfigure different communication options in order to fully exploit multiple communication capabilities that satisfy diverse application requirements.

In addition to these basic functionalities, other functional layers or modules should be designed to support the control plane and handle application-related tasks. For example, to help the controller build and maintain real-time network status, a layer that gathers the information of local topology could be designed. As data aggregation and in-network data processing operations effectively reduce the number of required data transmissions in order to save precious energy as well as communication bandwidth, specific layers should be designed to handle such operations.

In [7], OpenFlow-enabled static and mobile sensor nodes are proposed, which are called OF-node and OF-AUVs, respectively. In each OF-node and OF-AUVs, OpenFlow-based forwarding tables take charge of the routing decisions of data forwarding operations. An OF-node also includes a cognitive module to perform run-time switching operation among multiple software-defined hardware front-ends intelligently. Apart from these components, a local neighbor table is included in an OF-node to store instant neighbors that are one or more hops away. To deal with data aggregation or in-network data processing tasks, a local data storage and processing component is designed. A node cooperation module is also designed in an OF-node to improve the cooperation efficiency among static or mobile OF-based nodes. Furthermore, security components such as context-awareness and physical layer security protocols are also designed in the OF-based nodes.

In the application plane, versatile applications (e.g., ocean monitoring, underwater surveillance, disaster salvation and underwater navigation) can be incorporated. The successful implementation of these applications needs coordination between the control plane and the data plane. Accordingly, the resources of the underlying infrastructure in the data plane can be utilized efficiently via a set of northbound and southbound APIs. Furthermore, with the help of low-and high-level virtualization, the resources of the network infrastructure can be abstracted and divided into multiple isolated slices, which support multiple applications simultaneously.

div.head: G. Brief Summary and Further Discussions
div.p: In this subsection, we first give a brief summary of existing research, and then present discussions on the future research.

1) Brief Summary of Existing Research: Overall, the underwater SDN-enabled networking is in its early stage, and several pioneer works provided significant contributions from several aspects (e.g., general architecture, security, mobile network, routing, simulation and testbed) in this area [5], [7], [68], [172], [173], [181]. A SDN-enabled architecture generally consists of data plane, control plane and application plane, which supports multi-application, multi-modality hardware front-ends, network interoperability, evolvability and efficiency in the management process [5], [7].

SoftWater is the first comprehensive SDN-enabled architecture [5]. To facilitate resource sharing and management, both softwarization and virtualization techniques are integrated into the architecture. By softwarizing physical-and MAC layer in OpenFlow-supported OF-sensor as software-defined radio, it is much easier to reconfigure and utilize hardware resources in a flexible manner. Two levels of virtualization techniques have been utilized fully, and so multiple virtual V-OF-sensors can be created within a single OF-sensor that share the same underlying hardware resources. After that, these low-level virtualized infrastructure resources are sliced into multiple isolated virtual networks to serve different applications. In addition to basic functions of the SDN-enabled architecture, a set of well-designed management tools (e.g., routing control, and out-of-band traffic control, mobility control and fault recovery) guarantee specific requirements of different applications (e.g., sensing, data analysis, security and QoS).

As the architecture with single controller has its disadvantage in terms of robustness, an architecture with multiple controllers that consists of both primary and secondary OFcontrollers, is proposed in [7]. Hence, the architecture takes the advantages of both centralized and distributed control functions, which not only increases the network robustness, but reduces the overall control overhead. Furthermore, several other techniques such as cross-layer, context-awareness and network cognition are incorporated in the system to fortify network security. For example, cross-layer techniques improve both network efficiency and the implementation of effective security mechanisms. Meanwhile, the node and network cognition not only enhance communication adaptability, but help in identifying potential security threats faster.

Underwater mobile sensor networks have the advantage of operating in large areas of the ocean freely, and therefore it has great underwater application prospects. In [172], an AUV based mobile SDN-enabled architecture is proposed, in which a static centralized controller leverages a dedicated channel to control the AUV networking. A similar mobile architecture is presented in [173], which is used for the search or surveillance missions. In this architecture, multiple unmanned underwater support vehicles serve as sub-controllers which control and coordinate multiple AUVs. The main controller is resided in a ship to communicate and control these sub-controllers around it. The control plane uses the dedicated channel, namely JANUS, for the dissemination of robust control messages.

As simulation and experimental platforms greatly facilitate the SDN-enabled development of UWSNs [26], research has been carried out along with network testing and validation in [68], [172]. In [68], a SDN-enabled underwater simulation platform is developed based on OpenNet and ns-3 [182]. In addition to that, the aforementioned mobile architectures are implemented with initial testing in a small-scale modified testbed, WaterCom [183]. As those testing are experimented in a water tank with six fixed OFDM acoustic modems, more evaluations of these networks especially in the open ocean are expected to verify and reveal practical factors which affect these SDN-enabled architectures. Therefore, more SDN-based simulation tools, testbeds or evaluation platforms should be designed to sufficiently evaluate SDN-enabled protocols in real scenarios in order to facilitate developing more practical and reliable SDN-enabled UWSNs.

2) Further Discussions: The SDN paradigm is generally a software-defined programming approach with many potential benefits. However, due to the inherent characteristics of UWSNs and the challenges of enabling SDN for them, a number of open issues need further exploration. For example, SDN-enabled solutions may be energy efficient (e.g., with optimized routing), but it also introduces a large level of overhead from control traffic especially in dynamic and unreliable underwater communication environments with the rapid changes of network topology. Nevertheless, the benefits of simplification and evolvability derived from SDN may be more important than general performance improvement in terms of energy efficiency. Therefore, under such specific scenarios, tradeoffs may be inevitable for the design of software-defined networks.

As both terrestrial WSNs and UWSNs have many common features (e.g., application oriented, energy constrained and limited capacity) which need to be tackled when SDN is enabled for them, the existing literature for terrestrial WSNs may shed light on the application of SDN in UWSNs. For example, as data aggregation can reduce the number of data transmissions both for underwater and terrestrial WSNs, an in-network packet processing layer designed for terrestrial wireless software-defined networks can be used for underwater networks with minor modification [171]. However, UWSNs also have several unique characteristics which should be considered carefully. Therefore, most of the terrestrial SDN protocols cannot be directly adopted for underwater SDN. For example, in a terrestrial SDN-based architecture for WSNs, a network operating system layer is used to collect topology information [184]. When it is used in the mobile UWSNs, the slow speed of acoustic communication as well as unreliable communication links should be taken into account in order to obtain and maintain an accurate network topology.

div.head: V. UNDERWATER NETWORK FUNCTION VIRTUALIZATION (NFV) A. Basic Concept
div.p: NFV is a promising technique to decouple network functions from underlying hardware deployment, and virtualize the entire physical computing resources into softwarized network functions, which can be adaptively reconfigured and allocated quickly with high flexibility to meet diverse requirements [78].

The concept of network virtualization and NFV have slight difference [79], [185]. In terrestrial networks, NFV emphasizes on separating network functions from hardware, and hosting them on servers and cloud data centers for better management of network services, while in sensor network domain, those concepts focus on virtualization of resources for better management, such as allocation, reconfiguration and utilization.

div.head: B. Benefits of NFV
div.p: NFV is a fundamental technology that can be broadly integrated into the design of underwater software-defined networks to facilitate infrastructure utilization. The primary benefits of this concept are summarized as follows.

-Multi-Application Support: Leveraging network virtualization, the network resources of both hardware and software, sensing capability, bandwidth allocation, multiple communication options, are abstracted and integrated into complex software entities. Hence, it provides users flexibility to implement multiple underwater applications efficiently by sharing the same underlying physical communication infrastructure [78]. For example, the softwarized resources can be divided into several disjoint virtual networks, and hence multiple applications can cooperate simultaneously on each virtual network without interfering with each other [5]. Accordingly, NFV not only enables a reusable network, but improves the efficiency of network resources.

-Deployment of Novel Applications: As network-level virtualization supports multiple applications on a single sensor network, it greatly advances network innovation of underwater technologies by allocating resources of isolated networks to test novel schemes or algorithms in field-level deployment environments. These real-time field-level experiments not only effectively enhance the quality of performance evaluation compared to underwater simulations and emulations, but greatly reduce field-level experimental costs since underwater fieldlevel experimental testbeds are extremely expensive [26].

-Implementation of Sensing-as-a-Service Model: Network virtualization supports the implementation of sensing-as-aservice model, such as sensors-as-a-service or sensing-as-aservice. Since the isolated virtualization of networks can be dedicated to different operators and service providers, this significantly enhances the sharing of network infrastructure and facilitates the implementation of different sensing-as-aservice models accordingly. The utilization model of serviceoriented sensor networks not only greatly reduces the high costs of UWSNs, but also boost their overall development process.

div.head: C. Implementation of Virtualization Concept for Sensor Networks
div.p: The concept of virtualization is applied to both terrestrial and underwater sensor networks [5], [11], [77], [78], [186]. Generally, virtualiztion can be further classified into node and network-levels.

-Node-Level Virtualization: The node-level virtualization is a low-level technique that aims to virtualize the resources of a single node. Thus, these softwarized hardware resources can be shared among multiple applications by executing multiple tasks sequential or concurrently, in which corresponding tasks are executed either by sensor node OS, middleware or virtual sensors [5].

This level of virtualization primarily focuses on physical resources of a single node in order to increase the utilization efficiency of node-level resources. For example, in [5], a lowlevel resource scheduler, which is called Wireless Hypervisor, is proposed based on this concept. In addition to that, as it focuses on physical layer virtualization, SDR can easily be integrated into it to enable reconfiguration ability. Furthermore, with such integration, it is easier to implement effective tools to support and manage multi-modal modems (e.g., acoustic, optical and EM) while jointly utilizing their advantages.

-Network-Level Virtualization: Based on the node-level virtualization, network-level virtualization is a higher level network resource abstraction mechanism. Unlike node-level virtualization to handle the resources of a single node, the network-level virtualization copes with the requirements of more complex applications by scheduling and allocating resources within the entire network in a cooperative manner to satisfy the demands of diverse applications. While virtualizing network resources, both slicing and merging techniques can be used. It is natural to merge multiple sensor networks into single or multiple virtualized networks (or virtual sensors) in order to have more network resources or dedicated sensing capability [11]. As softwarized units, those virtual sensors abstract direct measurement activities of physical sensors, and therefore it is convenient to program those nodes for tailored virtual sensing.

For example, in [11], virtualized underwater sensors are implemented in a cluster-based underwater sensor network for detecting sparse events. Leveraging the fact that the locations of the events are sparsely distributed, compressive sensing is implemented on the virtual sensors in order to reconstruct event measurements for accurate detection with low sensing overhead. Similarly, the softwarized resources can also be partitioned or sliced into logically isolated virtual subset of networks, which will significantly improve resource efficiency and satisfy application diversity by running dedicated applications on those isolated virtual networks. Furthermore, via sophisticated resource scheduling schemes, the optimal utilization of network resources can be achieved while satisfying QoS requirements of each application.

A network-level resource management framework, called network hypervisor, is proposed in [5]. Network hypervisor takes charge high-level scheduling and allocation of network resources based on the demands of each application which runs on sliced virtual networks. The aim of network hypervisor is to achieve optimized utilization of network resources while considering that the resources are spectrum, sensors, radio access options (e.g., acoustic, optical and EM), under the QoS requirements of different applications (e.g., data rate, energy consumption, sensing frequency and coverage).

div.head: VI. INTERNET OF UNDERWATER THINGS (IOUT) AND CLOUD COMPUTING
div.p: The Internet of Things (IoTs) emerges in order to connect and control smart things for providing Internet-based services, in which these intelligent things can be reached at any time in any place [187], [188]. Based on IoTs, cloud computing enables on demand access to shared configurable computing resource pools in a convenient manner [189], [190]. As cloud computing provides computation abstraction to accelerate sensor network data sharing, and to enable sensor-as-a-service or sensing-as-a-service oriented networks, it has been integrated to WSNs. For example, sensor-cloud is one of such creations, the concept of which manages connected sensors, data storage, processing and sharing [85]. Although most of the existing UWSNs currently are isolated from the Internet [6], these paradigms and concepts are on the way to be incorporated to UWSNs. In this section, we discuss the development and the advancement of these areas in UWSNs.

div.head: A. Basic Concept of IoUTs
div.p: The concept of IoUTs tries to connect all underwater sensors deployed in oceans, lakes, rivers and so on, in order to construct a grand underwater network to facilitate the digitization of those areas as well as resources utilization [13], [14]. Under the concept of IoUT, underwater smart things can be reached anywhere, anytime and by anyone in order to enhance the sharing of information. For example, via embedded sensors in those things, IoUT has the capability of sensing the environment in real-time continuously. Accordingly, the information gathered by those smart things enable information sharing services via cloud computing or AI technology.

In addition to that, the concept of IoUT greatly improve the ability to reach, manage and utilize the resources of sensor networks effectively and efficiently. For example, via Internet, both static and mobile sensor nodes can be reached, and then be reconfigured and reprogrammed [6]. Keeping underwater things online also simplifies the network monitoring and diagnosing process as their status information can be logged and monitored in real-time.

The paramount benefit is derived from the fact that IoUTs transform the traditional application-oriented sensor networks to sensing-as-as-service networks. For example, the real-time ocean data, which are collected by floating underwater sinks or gateways, can be shared among different end-users around the world easily via the Internet. Furthermore, leveraging cloud computing, more complex data processing techniques can be used to produce high value information from huge volume of sensed data to serve more end-users. More importantly, coupled with the emerging technology, such as NFV, UWSNs can evolve towards sensing-service-oriented infrastructure, which provide on-demand services around the world via the Internet.

div.head: B. Connection and Control of Underwater Things
div.p: To realize IoUTs, underwater things should firstly be connected to the Internet in real-time so that these devices can be reached and controlled remotely at any place and anytime. Several papers explored how to reach and control underwater IoTs [6], [38]. In the following, we introduce two approaches to reach and control underwater things, e.g., via gateways or the IP-based technique.

1) Gateway-based Approach: This approach uses communication gateways to reach and control underwater things. It is natural to use gateways to reach and control underwater things since they are usually mounted on floating buoys, ships or onshore stations, and are equipped with multiple communication models (e.g., acoustic, RF and optical), plenty of battery power as well as Internet connectivity. Gateway provides a common bridge to convert and transform different communication protocols to communicate with each other, and uses smart tunneling technologies to manage interactions among heterogeneous devices.

Several famous long-term sea-trial underwater network projects, such as SEAWEB, Ocean-TUNE and SUNRISE, are among the forefront research groups that use gateways to handle underwater things [38], [191], [192]. In a SEAWEB experiment on 2003, two Racom gateway nodes are tested to reach and control both static and mobile nodes successfully [191]. In Ocean-TUNE UCONN testbed, buoy nodes are equipped with multiple modems (e.g., RF, CDMA, OFDM and Teledyne Benthos) and act as gateways with unique IP address, which can be accessed via onshore computers [192]. Via a web-based GUI and an acoustic remote control module, underwater things can be remotely controlled and reprogrammed according to the requirements of different applications.

In SUNRISE project, an interface SUNRISE GATE is designed to connect, communicate and reconfigure heterogeneous underwater things in different testbeds [38], [193]. SUNRISE GATE provides both low-level and high-level access for end-users. For low-level access, through a unified web interface, underwater devices can be reserved and monitored (e.g., positions and environmental conditions). SUNRISE GATE also provides high-level direct accessibility feature via a shell interface to conduct complex reconfigurations, such as modem firmware updating.

Gateway-based approach is easier to deploy, but it heavily depends on centralized communication techniques, which limit interoperability among nodes. Another problem is its scalability, i.e., as the number of nodes increases, the gateway may become a bottle-neck due to heavy traffic.

2) IP-based Approach: This approach directly connects underwater things to the Internet just like traditional IPbased networks. In [6], an IP-based approach is proposed, in which an adaptive IP-compatible layer enables commercial underwater devices for being capable of interoperating with traditional TCP/IP stacks. The adaptation layer resides in between the network layer and the link layer in order to keep the original IP-stack unaltered to the greatest extent.

The proposed network consists of two types of nodes, which are border routers and underwater nodes. The border routers are mounted on ships, buoys or onshore stations with direct Internet connectivity. The entire network is divided into multiple subsets, and there is one border router and multiple underwater nodes in each subset. With the help of the adaptation layer, the border router has one-hop virtual links to reach each of the underwater nodes in its subnet. However, these virtual links are originally realized via multi-hop interior mesh routing paths in order to reduce energy consumption and prevent interference with other nodes.

Similar to 6LowWPAN [194], that makes terrestrial WSNs IPv6 compatible, the adaptation layer performs header compression as well as fragmentation. However, this scheme also takes underwater energy consumption and time-varying channel into consideration in order to infer optimal packet size. The proposed scheme is implemented and evaluated in commercial Teledyne Benthos modem (e.g., SM-75), and demonstrated the proof of achieving both energy efficiency and effective interoperability.

C. Cloud Computing for UWSNs 1) Basic Concept: As an emerging information technology, cloud computing was initially developed for Internet-based networks [195], [196], and later it was extended to wireless sensor networks [197], [198]. The adoption of cloud computing improves the performance of sensor networks in terms of energy efficiency, computing capability and service quality via service-oriented networks [199]. More recently, sensorcloud has been proposed to integrate sensor networks with cloud computing tightly in order to fulfill more complex service-oriented application requirements [84], [85], [200], [201]. Coupled with IoTs, cloud computing offers serviceoriented resources, such as hardware, software and sensed data in different geographical locations around the world to anyone who needs them. Furthermore, integrating other cloud computing paradigms (e.g., fog computing and edge computing [202]- [204]) into UWSNs pour new vitality for further development.
2) Benefits: As UWSNs suffer from severe resource constraints, such as limited computing power, memory and battery supply, applying cloud computing to UWSNs will bring several benefits as follows.
-Sensing as a Service: The Internet and cloud computing enable everything as a service in three service models, such as infrastructure-as-a-service, platform-as-a-service and software-

The common characteristic of those models is to reallocate resources (e.g., software, hardware and data) as a service. In sensor network domain, those models have other names, such as sensors-as-service or sensing-as-a-service. The goal of those models is to transform traditional sensor into service-oriented sensor networks by exploiting the capability of both IoUTs and distributed cloud computing platforms.

-Cost Effective Resource Sharing: Currently, both the deployment and the maintenance costs of UWSNs are extremely expensive. Consequently, cloud computing and network virtualization enable sharing of network resources, and more endusers are able to reach and use the infrastructure via multiple applications. Hence, the overall cost of underwater networks is significantly reduced. Furthermore, end-users do not require to worry about the details of underlying networks, so they can focus on the utilization of sensed data.

-Scalable Resource Management: While leveraging cloud connection, diverse UWSNs which are deployed in different geographical locations can be virtualized as a single resource pool. Hence, these softwarized and virtualized resources can be elastically allocated and released as required. Consequently, it is easier to control and optimize resource utilization under pre-defined requirements of different metrics.

-Analysis, Visualization and Trend Prediction: The powerful computing capacity of the cloud computing technique naturally compensates drawbacks of traditional sensor networks with constrained computing capacity and limited processing power. By connecting sensed data to cloud computing platforms, complex data analysis tools and visualization techniques can be used to facilitate the development of UWSNs. It is also possible to exploit AI-based techniques (e.g., deep learning) [205] in order to improve real-time prediction capability.
3) Implementation: Integrating the Internet and cloud computing into UWSNs is relatively an emerging field, and we illustrate their recent development as follows.

-Early Cloud: At the early stage, the integration of cloud computing and sensor networks focuses on transferring sensed data to cloud computing platforms. This low-level integration primarily exploits cloud platforms as sensor data processing units and data sharing centers. For example, in [206], underwater sensed data is transferred to a cloud computing platform, and then the data is processed, visualized and accessed by end-users via network interfaces. In [12], the surface sink acts as a gateway between sensor networks and cloud computing platform, and intelligent middlewares are responsible for the required management and interaction between them. In largescale UWSNs, if all the sensed data are transmitted to the cloud platform, the gateways may become a bottle neck in terms of high latency, high energy consumption and high traffic. To mitigate those problems, the fog computing and edge computing paradigms can be applied in UWSNs to allow most of the sensed data being processed firstly at where they are generated instead of sending all these sensed data to the remote data center for cloud computing.

-Sensor-Cloud: Sensor-cloud implements virtualization concept on the cloud computing platforms and decouples the network owners from the users, which results in the creation of virtual sensors from underlying physical sensors and hardware. Each virtual sensor is created from one or multiple physical sensors, while multiple virtual sensors form a big virtual sensor group. These virtual sensors are created or destroyed on demand as required. The virtual sensors are also programmable. Different from programmable underwater SDMs that focus on the reconfigurable physical and MAC layers, virtual sensors primarily provide programmability feature in order to satisfy on-demand application service requirements.

div.head: VII. SUMMARY AND FUTURE DIRECTIONS
div.p: In this section, we first briefly summarize the softwaredefined technologies in this paper, and then discuss several future research directions.

A. Summary of Software-defined Technologies 1) Description of General Category: We generally categorize software-defined technologies in terms of three groups, i.e., node-level, network-level and application-level, according to their functions.

-Node-Level Technology: The node-level technology primarily solves the issues related to physical and MAC layers. SDR is such a node-level technique, which aims to empower sensor nodes with intelligence. Via this, sensor nodes have self-adaptation capability to deal with the dynamic changes of environments, and satisfy different demands of diverse applications (e.g., communication channel, multi-modal communication, multi-sensors and so on).

-Network-Level Technology: Network-level technologies are to improve the efficiency of network resources and simplify network management. Both SDN and NFV are network-level approaches. Naturally, the network-level techniques require the support of node devices. However, those devices are no longer real hardware assets, rather they are softwarized and virtualized entities that can be utilized and managed more conveniently.

-Application-Level Technology: The application-level technologies are to facilitate the versatile requirements of underwater applications, which are achieved by high-level abstractions of underlying software-defined architectures, such as SDN and NFV. Hence, end-users are just required to focus on well-defined APIs for implementing specific application policy engines [146]. Both IoUTs and cloud computing are considered as application-level technologies, which will propel conventional sensor networks to evolve towards sensing-as-aservice networks.

2) Programmability Analysis: One basic principle behind software-defined technologies is to improve network programmability [207], in which both the hardware and software of the network can be controlled and utilized fully to satisfy the requirements of different applications. From this point of view, all the software-defined technologies used in UWSNs, such as SDR, SDN and NFV, are the part of efforts to enable programmable UWSNs, in order to improve network flexibility, adaptivity, scalability, evolvability and resource utilization efficiency.

In a programmable network, most of the protocol stacks are implemented in software. However, in terms of programmability, these software-defined technologies have different priorities, which is illustrated in Fig. 11. We use different colors to represent the programmability level from low to high, where green represents the highest degree and grey represents the lowest degree.

Generally, SDR-SDM mainly focuses on physical layer programmability, whereas SDR-CR concentrates on the programmability of MAC layer. Both the SDN and NFV paradigms deal with the programmability of network layer by abstracting network resources, and hence they are correlated to each other. However, they have different emphasis on different aspects of the network and have different primary goals accordingly.

SDN creates centralized network control abstractions with the aim to enhance network flexibility and simplify both network innovation and management. In contrast, NFV abstracts network functions and services from physical hardware resources in order to improve resource utilization efficiency. Both IoUTs and cloud computing (e.g., sensor-cloud) primarily focus on application layer programmability by providing well-defined APIs to accelerate network sharing as well as enable sensing-as-a-service oriented networks.

3) Analysis of Complementary Characteristics: Currently, most of the software-defined technologies have been developed individually. However, some of them have similarities, and are even complementary to each other. For example, both NFV and sensor-cloud aim at resource sharing, but NFV is in favor of infrastructure resource sharing while sensor-cloud concentrates on high level sensed data sharing.

Both the SDN and NFV are created to improve network flexibility and scalability in order to speed up application innovation and network evolution. However, they are not dependent on each other. As NFV decouples network functions from network hardware to implement sophisticated data-plane functionalities with the help of virtualization concept, they are complementary to each other. Therefore, they can be combined and integrated together for the implementation of better NFV, and simplify the operations that runn on software-defined networks.
