Additionally, multiple software-defined technologies may be complementary to each other. In such efforts, both SDR and NFV are integrated into the design of underwater software-defined networks [5], [208].

B. Future Directions 1) Integration of Complementary Software-Defined Architecture Design: Although software-defined techniques have different priorities at different layers in terms of OSI network model, some of them are also complementary to each other. Hence, integrating multiple techniques together and building novel architectures would significantly enhance the capability of those emerging technologies. However, as most of these technologies are isolatedly created and developed, when combining them together, more efforts should be made to prevent complications among different techniques, e.g., to modify, redesign part of them or make tradeoffs in order to design optimized and robust software-defined architectures.

Practically, since there is no one-fits-all architecture that satisfies the diverse application requirements, we advocate that software-defined architectures are the flexible ones to program the entire protocol stack from top to bottom fully. The top-down complementary software-defined architecture can be regarded as a novel transformation of modular-based architecture, which can be thoroughly programmed across the entire protocol stack, e.g., from the physical layer to the application layer, to satisfy the dynamic requirements of application services.

2) Cross-Layer Design: In order to achieve optimized network performance under harsh communication environments and resource-constrained underwater devices, crosslayer design is a well-accepted approach in UWSNs by making the lower layer information available to the higher layers [167], [209]. This approach can be implemented in softwaredefined network architectures, and allows shared parameters or information transfer among the softwarized layers in order to execute optimized protocols or algorithms.

For example, a modular-based cross-layer approach, Cross-Flow, is proposed for terrestrial wireless radio networks [210], which takes the advantages of the integrated SDR and SDN-based architecture. CrossFlow provides physical layer abstractions and interfaces for the centralized controller to manipulate in order to realize real-time reconfigurations of the underlying physical infrastructures. When such concept is used in UWSNs, the fact that underwater nodes may be equipped with multiple communication front-ends (e.g., acoustic, optical and EM) should be taken into account. Therefore, the controller has more options to select and control. Accordingly, the controller needs to collect and monitor multiple spatiotemporally varying channels state information in order to control the underlying infrastructures efficiently.

Currently, there is a research trend of integrating multiple software-defined techniques together in order to reap greater benefits from these integrations. As more technologies are integrated to each other, implementing a vertical cross-layer technique creates new challenges to be solved. For example, when combining SDN and sensor-cloud techniques together, the cross-layer design should consider the coordination of northbound APIs with the requirements of sensor-cloud applications.

3) Cognitive Oriented Sensor Networks: Currently, cognitive acoustic sensor networks primarily leverage SDR for the management of dynamic underwater spectrum. However, we advocate that underwater cognitive sensor networks should not be confined only to this area. This paradigm should be implemented towards smart sensor nodes as well as smart sensor networks. For example, by integrating information sensing, data analysis, decision making and execution of actions, we can develop cognitive-oriented self-adaptive intelligent sensor networks. With the help of cloud computing and IoUTs, the ultimate goal of cognitive paradigm is to bring the intelligent automated networks in reality.

4) AI Support Design: In the recent years, the development of AI is rapid in wireless networks, and AI-based technologies (e.g., machine learning, reinforcement learning and deep learning) have been used in wireless sensor networks [211]. On the other hand, currently, underwater sensor nodes have more powerful computational capability, and hence it is the time to apply AI-based technologies to UWSNs [26], [212], [213]. AI-based technologies would create new opportunities for UWSNs, and benefit both for software-defined sensor nodes and software-defined networks which enable more intelligent networks in the near future.

By integrating AI-based techniques into software-defined architectures or protocols design, sensor nodes will become smarter with real-time self-adaptation capability to cope with harsh ocean environments while targeting on the improvement of communication efficiency as well as the utilization of underwater spectrum intelligently. Implementing AI-based techniques such as reinforcement learning and deep learning into network layer architecture will increase network-level intelligence in terms of environmental adaptability and resource efficiency by pre-training networks with automatic extracted features from the targeted deployment area.

5) Evolution of Isolated Networks towards Service-Oriented Networks: As of today, most of the UWSNs are isolatedly developed and some networks are even used only for military applications. Accordingly, the network infrastructure and sensed data are forbidden to commercial utilization, which further hurdle the proliferation of underwater technologies for commercial market. As IoUTs are the primary foundations to develop smart ocean, the potential demand of commercial is surging. However, until now, UWSNs still lack the capability to meet such demands.

Therefore, it might be both economically beneficial and practical to enlarge the limited commercial market by transforming the conventional underwater networks towards service-oriented networks. Since both the assets and maintenance costs of underwater networks are currently extremely high, developing open and shared service-oriented networks is expected to reduce the necessary cost for scientific or commercial utilization significantly.

Technically, service-oriented networks require openness of both the network infrastructure and the sensed data. Therefore, we need to exploit the potential power of these emerging software-defined techniques, and conquer urgent problems along the road towards realizing sensing-as-a-service networks. For example, a service-oriented UWSN requires network standardization to enhance the interoperability of underwater communication assets. Implementing software-defined technologies in physical layer will greatly enhance the interoperability of underwater modems. Supported by NATO, JANUS is also a standardization effort to develop an international standard underwater communication language [134]. Other techniques such as sensor-cloud also needs further efforts to accelerate the transformation of traditional networks.

div.head: VIII. CONCLUSION
div.p: In this paper, we presented a survey on software-defined technologies of UWSNs (via programming all layers of OSI model), which include SDR (e.g., SDM and software-defined CR), network virtualization, software-defined networks, IoUTs and cloud computing. While describing each of these technologies, we highlight that programmability is a feature which can be used for increasing network flexibility and adaptability. Among these technologies, SDMs have been studied for many years. However, we argue that many of the recently emerging software-defined technologies, such as CR, NFV, SDN and sensor-cloud, provide potential opportunities to tackle some inherent challenges of UWSNs.

Although these technologies have different programming priorities that aim at different layers, some of them are complementary to each other. Leveraging this characteristic, those techniques can be combined together to design softwaredefined cross-layer programmable networks with improved resource utilization efficiency. We also discussed several research issues for future advancement in this domain. There is no doubt that these technologies will propel further development of UWSNs when researchers learn how to leverage their advantages and apply them to UWSNs. We hope that this paper will inspire and promote more research activities in this area, and we believe that the utilization of these novel softwaredefined technologies will significantly enhance the evolution of UWSNs towards the next-generation more sophisticated ones. and GDUPS (2015), University of Macau Grant SRG2015-00050-FST. Kaishun Wu is the corresponding author. We thank the anonymous reviewers and the editors for their valuable advice and their insightful comments.
